IM Pharm

Wednesday, 4 June 2025

10:00 PM

ID

Question

Explanation

1

Which of the following inhaled anaestheticsDOES NOTtrigger malignant hyperthermia?

A. Ether

B. Sevoflurane

C. Halothane

D. Nitrous oxide

A. Ether – Wrong

B. Sevoflurane – Wrong

C. Halothane – Wrong

D. Nitrous oxide – Correct

Explanation:

Malignant hyperthermia is triggered by exposure to volatile (inhaled) anesthetic agents and depolarizing muscle relaxants such as succinylcholine. According to Katzung, “malignant hyperthermia is a heritable genetic disorder of skeletal muscle that occurs in susceptible individuals exposed to volatile anesthetics” (e.g., halothane, enflurane, isoflurane, sevoflurane) (see Chapter 16 and Table 16–4). Succinylcholine may also precipitate an episode, but nitrous oxide is not a volatile halogenated anesthetic and therefore does not trigger malignant hyperthermia .

  • Ether (A) is a volatile anesthetic (though used less commonly today), and volatile agents as a class can precipitate malignant hyperthermia.
  • Sevoflurane (B) and Halothane (C) are both halogenated volatile anesthetics known to trigger malignant hyperthermia.
  • Nitrous oxide (D) is neither a halogenated nor a volatile anesthetic in the sense that it does not interact with the ryanodine receptor to cause the uncontrolled calcium release responsible for malignant hyperthermia.

Relevant Katzung Notes:

  • Malignant hyperthermia presents with a rapid rise in end‐tidal CO₂, muscle rigidity, tachycardia, hyperthermia, and rhabdomyolysis in genetically susceptible patients exposed to triggering agents (volatile anesthetics or succinylcholine).
  • Immediate treatment involves discontinuation of the triggering agent, hyperventilation with 100% oxygen, active cooling, and administration of dantrolene, which acts to inhibit calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum .

 

 

2

Which is the most potent opioid analgesic?

A. Morphine

B. Buprenorphine

C. Fentanyl

D. Oxycodone

A. Morphine – Wrong

B. Buprenorphine – Wrong

C. Fentanyl – Correct

D. Oxycodone – Wrong

Explanation:

Among the opioids listed, fentanyl is by far the most potent. In Katzung’s overview of phenylpiperidines, it states that “among the phenylpiperidines, these opioids differ mainly in their potency and biodisposition. Sufentanil is five to seven times more potent than fentanyl. Carfentanil is approximately 100 times more potent than fentanyl” . By implication, fentanyl itself is already extremely potent compared to morphine, buprenorphine, and oxycodone:

  • Morphine (A) is the prototypical μ‐agonist, but its potency is set as the standard (1×).
  • Buprenorphine (B), although very high‐affinity at μ receptors, is a partial agonist; its analgesic effect per milligram is greater than morphine’s, but it does not exceed fentanyl's full‐agonist potency.
  • Fentanyl (C) is a full μ agonist that is roughly 100× more potent than morphine on a microgram‐to‐microgram basis (as noted, agents like sufentanil and carfentanil are even more potent “beyond fentanyl”) .
  • Oxycodone (D) has about 1.5–2× the potency of oral morphine, but it remains far less potent than fentanyl when comparing equipotent dosing.

Relevant Katzung Notes:

  • Katzung classifies fentanyl under “Phenylpiperidines,” highlighting that “fentanyl is one of the most widely used agents in the family of synthetic opioids” and emphasizing its very high potency relative to morphine. Levels above fentanyl—sufentanil (5–7× fentanyl) and carfentanil (~100× fentanyl)—underscore fentanyl’s position already near the top of potency among clinically used opioids .
  • Buprenorphine appears in Katzung as a “partial μ agonist • κ antagonist” used for moderate pain and maintenance programs; despite its high receptor affinity and long duration, its intrinsic activity is lower than fentanyl’s, making it less potent as an analgesic per microgram compared to a full agonist like fentanyl .
  • Oxycodone is listed as providing “dose‐dependent analgesia” in the phenanthrene subclass, with efficacy roughly comparable to morphine but not approaching fentanyl’s potency .

In summary, fentanyl’s full‐agonist profile and its established ~100× potency over morphine place it at the top of this list.

 

 

 

3

To which of the following does opioid tolerance not occur?

A. Cough suppression effect

B. Respiratory depression effect

C. Hypotensive effect

D. Miotic effect

A. Cough suppression effect – Wrong

B. Respiratory depression effect – Wrong

C. Hypotensive effect – Wrong

D. Miotic effect – Correct

Explanation:

Katzung’s Table 31–3 categorizes opioid effects by the degree of tolerance that may develop with repeated use. According to this table, tolerance does develop to analgesia, euphoria, sedation, respiratory depression, antidiuresis, nausea/vomiting, cough suppression, hypotension, and other effects. In contrast, tolerance does not develop (or develops minimally) to miotic, convulsant, and constipating actions of opioids .

  • Cough suppression (A): Moderate tolerance develops; over time higher doses are needed for the same antitussive effect .
  • Respiratory depression (B): High tolerance develops, though a tolerant individual can still be driven into arrest if doses are high enough or combined with other depressants .
  • Hypotensive effect (C): Tolerance develops to opioid-induced hypotension (via histamine release and vasodilation) with repeated dosing .
  • Miotic effect (D): Minimal or no tolerance develops to opioid-induced miosis; pupils remain constricted even after prolonged use .

Relevant Notes from Katzung:

  • Table 31–3 (“Degrees of tolerance that may develop to some of the effects of the opioids”) lists “Miosis” under the “Minimal or None” column, indicating tolerance does not occur to this effect.
  • Under that same discussion, Katzung explicitly states “tolerance develops to the antidiuretic, emetic, and hypotensive effects but not to the miotic, convulsant, and constipating actions” (Chapter 31) .

 

 

4

In bladder disorders

A. Oxybutinin selectively antagonises M2 receptors

B. Prazosin is a non selective for the alpha receptor antagonist useful intreating patients with BPH

C. Imipramine can be used in bladder dysfunction in the elderly

D. Nitrofurantoin has significant systemic effects

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. Oxybutynin selectively antagonises M2 receptors

Wrong

Oxybutynin is somewhat selective for M3 receptors, which mediate detrusor muscle contraction. It is not selective for M2 receptors. Its clinical benefit in overactive bladder stems from M3 antagonism, reducing involuntary detrusor contractions.

B. Prazosin is a non-selective α receptor antagonist useful in treating patients with BPH

"Correct"

Prazosin blocks all α₁ receptor subtypes (α₁A, α₁B, α₁D) and relaxes smooth muscle in the prostate and bladder neck, improving urine flow in BPH. It is non-subtype-selective, unlike newer agents (e.g., tamsulosin), but remains effective for BPH management.

C. Imipramine can be used in bladder dysfunction in the elderly

Correct

Imipramine, a tricyclic antidepressant with strong antimuscarinic (M₃) effects, has historically been used to reduce urinary incontinence in institutionalized elderly patients. It is moderately effective but carries a risk of significant CNS side effects.

D. Nitrofurantoin has significant systemic effects

Wrong

Nitrofurantoin is rapidly metabolized and excreted into the urine, achieving high urinary concentrations but minimal systemic antibacterial action under normal renal function. Systemic levels remain low, and significant systemic effects occur only if excretion is impaired (e.g., renal failure).

 

5

A 40-year-old man with chronic renal failure is intubated. Which neuromuscular blocking agent is most appropriate to maintain sedation?

A. Pancuronium

B. Atracurium

C. Vecuronium

D. Rocuronium

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. Pancuronium

Wrong

Pancuronium is eliminated primarily by renal excretion (≈80% unchanged in urine). In patients with chronic renal failure, its duration of action is significantly prolonged due to reduced clearance, making it less suitable.

B. Atracurium

Correct

Atracurium undergoes Hofmann elimination (spontaneous degradation at physiologic pH and temperature) and ester hydrolysis; it does not rely on renal function. Therefore, its duration of action remains predictable in renal failure.

C. Vecuronium

Wrong

Vecuronium is eliminated by both hepatic metabolism and renal excretion. Although hepatic clearance is primary, active metabolites can accumulate in renal failure and prolong neuromuscular blockade.

D. Rocuronium

Wrong

Rocuronium is eliminated via liver and kidneys (≈75–90% hepatic, remainder renal). In renal failure, its clearance decreases and duration can be prolonged. Hence, it is less ideal than atracurium.

 

 

 

 

Below is a comparison of the four nondepolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents (pancuronium, atracurium, vecuronium, rocuronium) using data from Katzung’s Table 27–1.

Agent

Elimination Pathway

Clearance(mL/kg/min)

Duration(minutes)

Relative Potency(vs. Tubocurarine)

Notes

Pancuronium

Renal (≈80 % excreted unchanged)

1.7–1.8

>35

6 (≈6× tubocurarine)

Long‐acting; markedly prolonged in renal failure due to reduced clearance.

Atracurium

Hofmann elimination (spontaneous;plus ester hydrolysis)

6.6

20–35

1.5

Undergoes organ‐independent degradation; predictable duration even in renal/liver impairment.

Vecuronium

Hepatic metabolism (75–90 %) plus renal excretion

3.0–5.3

20–35

6 (≈6× tubocurarine)

Intermediate‐acting; active metabolites may accumulate in renal failure, prolonging block.

Rocuronium

Hepatic metabolism (75–90 %) plus renal excretion

2.9

20–35

0.8 (≈0.8× tubocurarine)

Faster onset than vecuronium; clearance reduced in hepatic or renal dysfunction.
  • Pancuronium: Primarily excreted unchanged by the kidneys (~80 %). Because of its low clearance (1.7–1.8 mL/kg/min), its duration (>35 min) is prolonged in renal failure.
  • Atracurium: Eliminated via Hofmann degradation (pH/temperature–dependent) and nonspecific esterases, independent of hepatic or renal function. Clearance is relatively high (6.6 mL/kg/min), so it retains a predictable 20–35 min duration even in organ dysfunction.
  • Vecuronium: Undergoes both hepatic metabolism and renal excretion. Although its parent drug is cleared hepatically, the 3‐hydroxy metabolite may accumulate in renal failure, potentially extending its 20–35 min action.
  • Rocuronium: Also relies on hepatic metabolism (~75–90 %) with some renal excretion. With a clearance of 2.9 mL/kg/min and 20–35 min duration, it exhibits moderately prolonged blockade in severe hepatic or renal impairment.

Data derived from Katzung’s pharmacokinetic and dynamic properties of neuromuscular blocking drugs (Table 27–1).

 

 

6

Which of the following drugs does not interact with warfarin?

A. Phenobarbitone

B. Cephalosporins

C. Loop diuretics

D. Benzodiazepines

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

Phenobarbitone is a hepatic enzyme inducer (CYP450 inducer), which increases warfarin metabolism and reduces its anticoagulant effect. This interaction may lead to subtherapeutic INR and risk of thrombosis.

B

Incorrect

Cephalosporins can interact with warfarin by inhibiting vitamin K production by gut flora and impairing clotting factor synthesis, thereby increasing the risk of bleeding. Some cephalosporins (e.g., cefotetan, cefoperazone) also have hypoprothrombinemic effects.

C

Incorrect

Loop diuretics may alter warfarin effect indirectly by causing hypoproteinemia (reducing warfarin binding to albumin) or volume depletion, which can enhance anticoagulant effect. Though not a strong interaction, it's still clinically relevant.

D

Correct

Benzodiazepines (e.g., diazepam, lorazepam) do not significantly affect warfarin metabolism or its anticoagulant activity. They are generally considered safe to use concurrently.

7

A 30 year old male patient presents with an acute myocardial infarction. Which drug has most likely caused this?

A. Increased noradrenaline effects of cocaine

B. Monoamineoxidase inhibition by amphetamine derivative

C. Increased adrenalin production due to heroin

D. Increased serotonin due to fluoxetine

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Correct

Cocaine increases noradrenaline (and dopamine) at synapses by inhibiting their reuptake. This causes intense vasoconstriction, tachycardia, and increased myocardial oxygen demand, all of which can precipitate acute myocardial infarction (AMI), especially in young individuals without significant atherosclerosis.

B

Incorrect

Amphetamine derivatives also increase catecholamine release, but their primary mechanism is not monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibition. While they can cause hypertension and tachycardia, they are less commonly associated with AMI compared to cocaine.

C

Incorrect

Heroin is a CNS depressant and does not increase adrenaline production. It’s more associated with respiratory depression, sedation, and overdose—not acute coronary events.

D

Incorrect

Fluoxetine, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), increases serotonin levels. It can cause side effects like GI upset and sexual dysfunction but is not associated with AMI.

8

Which of the following drugs can accumulate to toxic levels in a previously stable patient when diuretic therapy is instituted?

A. Amiodarone

B. Lithium

C. Aspirin

D. Digoxin

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

Amiodarone has a very long half-life and is lipophilic, but its levels are not significantly affected by diuretics. It does not depend heavily on renal excretion, so diuretic-induced volume changes don't cause toxic accumulation.

B

Correct

Lithium is excreted by the kidneys, and its reabsorption in the renal tubules is closely linked to sodium handling. When diuretics (especially thiazides) are introduced, sodium is lost, and the kidney compensates by reabsorbing more lithium—leading to accumulation and potential toxicity, even in a previously stable patient.

C

Incorrect

Aspirin is mostly protein-bound and metabolized hepatically. While NSAIDs can affect renal function, aspirin levels are not significantly altered by diuretics in a toxicologically meaningful way.

D

Incorrect

Digoxin levels can be affected by electrolyte disturbances (especially hypokalemia) caused by diuretics, which can increase its toxicity without changing serum levels. However, it doesn’t accumulate due to diuretic therapy per se—just becomes more dangerous.

9

Potency is:

A. The concentration or dose of a drug required to produce a toxic effect in 50% of exposed subjects

B. The concentration or dose of a drug required to produce 50% of the drugs maximal effect

C. Proportional to therapeutic index

D. The maximal effect of a drug regardless of dose

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

This defines TD₅₀ (Toxic Dose 50), which refers to the dose that produces a toxic effect in 50% of subjects—not potency.

B

Correct

Potency refers to the amount (dose or concentration) of a drug needed to produce a given effect, typically 50% of the drug’s maximal effect (EC₅₀). A more potent drug requires a lower dose to achieve this.

C

Incorrect

Therapeutic index relates to the drug's safety margin (ratio of toxic to effective dose), not directly to potency. A drug can be very potent but have a narrow or wide therapeutic index independently.

D

Incorrect

This defines efficacy, not potency. Efficacy is the maximum effect a drug can produce, regardless of dose.

10

All the following drugs are anaesthetic agents except?

A. Midazolam

B. Etomidate

C. Glycopyrolate

D. Propofol

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

Midazolam is a short-acting benzodiazepine used for premedication and sedation during anesthesia. Though not a general anesthetic on its own, it is considered part of the anesthetic regimen.

B

Incorrect

Etomidate is a rapid-onset intravenous anesthetic agent used for induction of general anesthesia, especially in hemodynamically unstable patients.

C

Correct

Glycopyrrolate is an anticholinergic agent, not an anesthetic. It is used preoperatively to reduce secretions and prevent bradycardia but does not induce sedation or anesthesia.

D

Incorrect

Propofol is a widely used intravenous anesthetic agent for induction and maintenance of general anesthesia, as well as sedation in ICU settings.

 

11

Which of the following drugsdoes nothave an effect on AV nodal conduction?

A. Lignocaine

B. Verapamil

C. Sotalol

D. Amiodarone

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Correct

Lignocaine (Lidocaine) is a class IB antiarrhythmic that primarily affects ventricular myocytes, not the AV node. It has little to no effect on AV nodal conduction, making it useful for ventricular arrhythmias, not supraventricular ones.

B

Incorrect

Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker (Class IV antiarrhythmic) that significantly slows AV nodal conduction, making it effective for supraventricular tachyarrhythmias like AVNRT.

C

Incorrect

Sotalol is a non-selective beta-blocker with class III antiarrhythmic properties. It slows AV nodal conduction through its beta-blockade, and also prolongs repolarization via potassium channel blockade.

D

Incorrect

Amiodarone has multiple class effects (I, II, III, IV), and it does suppress AV nodal conduction, though not as potently or selectively as verapamil or beta-blockers. It is effective in both atrial and ventricular arrhythmias.

12

Regarding allopurinol, which of the following is incorrect?

A. It can cuase an acute attack of gout

B. It should be avoided in patients with renal impairment

C. It inhibits the metabolism of anicoagulants

D. It is used as an antiprotzoal agent

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Correct

Allopurinol can paradoxically trigger an acute gout attack when first started, due to mobilization of urate from tissues. This is why it’s often co-prescribed with colchicine or NSAIDs initially.

B

Incorrect

Allopurinol is not absolutely contraindicated in renal impairment but should be used with dose adjustments and caution. High doses in renal dysfunction can lead to toxicity (e.g., hypersensitivity reactions), but it's not to be avoided entirely. So, this statement is partially incorrect, but not the best "incorrect" option compared to D.

C

Correct

Allopurinol inhibits xanthine oxidase, which also affects the metabolism of drugs like azathioprine, mercaptopurine, and anticoagulants (e.g., warfarin). This can increase the anticoagulant effect, requiring careful monitoring.

D

Incorrect (Correct Answer)

Allopurinol is not an antiparasitic or antiprotozoal agent. It is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor used in the management of chronic gout and hyperuricemia. This is the clearly incorrect statement.

13

The risk of transient neurological symptoms is most likely to occur with which local anaesthetic?

A. Bupivacaine

B. Lignocaine

C. Prilocaine

D. Chloroprociane

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

Bupivacaine is known for cardiotoxicity at high doses but is not primarily associated with transient neurological symptoms (TNS).

B

Correct

Lignocaine (Lidocaine), especially when used in spinal anesthesia, has been strongly associated with a higher risk of transient neurological symptoms (TNS) — characterized by pain, dysesthesia, or weakness in the lower back, buttocks, and legs postoperatively, despite no nerve injury.

C

Incorrect

Prilocaine is less commonly associated with TNS and is more notable for the risk of methemoglobinemia at high doses.

D

Incorrect

Chloroprocaine has a short duration and low systemic toxicity. Though earlier formulations were neurotoxic, modern preservative-free versions are not significantly linked to TNS.

14

Which drug and side effect are incorrectly matched?

A. Phenobarbitol and enzyme induction

B. Sodiumvalpraote and idiosyncratic hepatic toxicity

C. Phenytoin and gum hypertrophy

D. Ethosuximide and hirsutism

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Correct

Phenobarbitone (Phenobarbital) is a potent enzyme inducer, particularly of the cytochrome P450 system, which can affect the metabolism of many other drugs.

B

Correct

Sodium valproate is well known to cause idiosyncratic hepatic toxicity, particularly in young children and those with mitochondrial disorders. Liver function must be monitored during therapy.

C

Correct

Phenytoin causes gingival (gum) hypertrophy, especially in children and with prolonged use. It also causes other side effects like hirsutism and cerebellar toxicity.

D

Incorrect (Correct Answer)

Ethosuximide is used for absence seizures and commonly causes GI upset and lethargy, but hirsutism is not a known side effect. Hirsutism is more commonly associated with phenytoin or sodium valproate.

15

The endogenous anticoagulantantithrombin IIIinhibits all the following clotting factors EXCEPT

A. Va

B. Xa

C. IXa

D. IIa

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Correct (EXCEPT)

Factor Va is a cofactor, not a serine protease, and is not directly inhibited by antithrombin III (ATIII). Instead, it is inactivated by activated protein C, not ATIII.

B

Incorrect

Factor Xa is a serine protease directly inhibited by ATIII, especially in the presence of heparin. It plays a key role in converting prothrombin to thrombin.

C

Incorrect

Factor IXa is also a serine protease and a target of ATIII inhibition, playing a role in the intrinsic coagulation pathway.

D

Incorrect

Factor IIa (thrombin) is one of the main targets of ATIII, which binds and inactivates it, especially when heparin is present, significantly accelerating the inhibition.

16

Labetalol has the following pharmacodynamic effect

A. B1 + B2 Antagonism

B. Alpha 1 + B1  Antagonism

C. Alpha 1 + B1 + B2  Antagonism

D. Alpha 1+ Alpha 2 + B1 + B2  Antagonism

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

Labetalol is not selective for just β-receptors; it also blocks α₁-receptors, so this option is incomplete.

B

Incorrect

While labetalol does block α₁ and β₁, it also has β₂ antagonism, though to a lesser extent—making this option also incomplete.

C

Correct

Labetalol is a mixed alpha- and beta-adrenergic antagonist, specifically blocking α₁, β₁, and β₂ receptors. This contributes to both vasodilation (via α₁ blockade) and reduced heart rate and contractility (via β₁ blockade), with some β₂ effects.

D

Incorrect

Labetalol does not block α₂ receptors. Blocking α₂ would actually increase norepinephrine release, which is not a feature of labetalol’s mechanism.

17

A 30yr female presents to the ED 5hrs post ingestion of a drug. She is agitated, hypertensive, febrile and is hyperreflexic with clonus. The most likely causative drug?

A. Prochlorperazine

B. Chlorpromazine

C. Fluoxetine

D. Benztropine

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

Prochlorperazine is a dopamine antagonist (antiemetic/antipsychotic) and is more commonly associated with extrapyramidal side effects, not the hyperreflexia, clonus, or autonomic instability seen in this case.

B

Incorrect

Chlorpromazine, a typical antipsychotic, can cause neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS), which includes rigidity (not clonus), altered mental status, and hyperthermia—but not hyperreflexia or clonus, making it less likely.

C

Correct

Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). The described symptoms — agitation, hypertension, hyperthermia, hyperreflexia, and clonus — are classic signs of serotonin syndrome, which is most consistent with this drug.

D

Incorrect

Benztropine is an anticholinergic used for Parkinsonism or extrapyramidal symptoms. Overdose causes anticholinergic toxicity (dry skin, mydriasis, urinary retention, confusion), but not clonus or hyperreflexia, making it unlikely here.

18

What is the earliest and most frequent neurological sing of an acute overdose of Lithium?

A. Tremor

B. Hyperreflexia

C. Confusion

D. Sedation

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Correct

Tremor (typically a fine postural tremor) is the earliest and most frequent neurological sign of acute or chronic lithium toxicity. It often appears even at therapeutic levels and is more pronounced in overdose.

B

Incorrect

Hyperreflexia can occur in moderate to severe lithium toxicity, but it is not an early sign. It tends to develop later, along with clonus or seizures.

C

Incorrect

Confusion is seen in more advanced toxicity, especially at higher serum lithium levels. It is not the earliest sign.

D

Incorrect

Sedation may occur with lithium toxicity, but it is less frequent and nonspecific compared to tremor, and not typically the first neurologic sign noted.

19

How much sodium is contained in a solution of 8.4% NAHCO3 (sodium bicarbonate)?

A. 3mmol/ml

B. 0.5mmol/ml

C. 2mmol/m/

D. 1mmol/ml

 

20

When given orally, what is the calcium channel blocker with the most rapid onset of action?

A. Felodopine

B. Diltiazem

C. Verapamil

D. Nifedipine

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

Felodipine is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker, but it has a delayed onset due to extended-release formulations, making it slower than nifedipine.

B

Incorrect

Diltiazem (a non-dihydropyridine) has a moderate onset of action and is often used in sustained-release forms. It doesn’t act as rapidly as immediate-release nifedipine.

C

Incorrect

Verapamil also has a moderate to slow onset, especially in oral form, and is often used for rate control rather than rapid BP reduction.

D

Correct

Nifedipine (immediate-release) has the most rapid onset of action among orally administered calcium channel blockers—typically within 20–30 minutes, making it historically used for hypertensive emergencies (although now avoided due to risks of sudden BP drops).

21

Regarding ergotamine, which of the following statements is incorrect?

A. It can be given parenterally

B. It works well in the early treatment of acute migraine

C. It causes vasoconstriction

D. It causes GI haemmorhage.

 

22

What medication is used to decontaminate the body following a toxic iron ingestion?

A. Charcoal

B. Penicillamine

C. Desferioxamine

D. EDTA

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

Activated charcoal does not bind iron effectively and is therefore not useful for decontaminating the GI tract in iron overdose. Gastric lavage or whole bowel irrigation is preferred in early cases.

B

Incorrect

Penicillamine is a chelating agent, but it is used for copper toxicity (e.g., Wilson’s disease), not iron.

C

Correct

Desferrioxamine is the specific chelating agent for iron toxicity. It binds free iron to form ferrioxamine, which is excreted in urine, often turning it a pink or reddish color. It is used in moderate to severe iron poisoning, especially if serum iron is high or symptoms are severe.

D

Incorrect

EDTA (ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) is used to chelate lead, not iron. It is ineffective in iron toxicity.

23

What effects do kappa receptors mediate?

A. Slows gastrointestinal transit

B. Respiratory depression

C. Antidepressant effects

D. Physical dependence

Here is the evaluation of each option based strictly on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Justification from Katzung

A. Slows gastrointestinal transit

✅ Correct

“Opioid receptors in the gastrointestinal tract mediate... slowed gastrointestinal transit.” Kappa receptors, being one of the opioid receptors, contribute to this effect. 901_Katzun Pharm Split_…

B. Respiratory depression

✅ Correct

“κ-receptor activation can produce respiratory depression, miosis, and sedation.” 901_Katzun Pharm Split_…

C. Antidepressant effects

❌ Wrong

Kappa receptor activation is associated with dysphoria and psychotomimetic effects, not antidepressant effects. Antidepressant activity is not a known function of κ-receptor activation.

D. Physical dependence

✅ Correct

“The κ and δ receptors also contribute to the development of physical dependence.” 901_Katzun Pharm Split_…

 

Let me know if you want a follow-up question explained or more MCQs answered.

24

Which drug does NOT have antiemetic properties?

A. Ketamine

B. Dexamethasone

C. Ondansetron

D. Midazolam

Here is the answer table based strictly on Katzung's Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (16th ed., 2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Direct Quote

A. Ketamine

✅ Correct

Ketamine is not described as having antiemetic effects. In fact, “Ketamine may cause unpleasant emergence reactions, including vivid dreams, hallucinations, and out-of-body experiences,” but there is no mention of antiemetic activity in Katzung1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

B. Dexamethasone

❌ Wrong

“Dexamethasone is frequently used as part of combination antiemetic regimens for chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. Ondansetron

❌ Wrong

“Ondansetron and related 5-HT3 antagonists are very effective antiemetics, particularly in the treatment of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Midazolam

❌ Wrong

While primarily a sedative, “Midazolam has also been found to have adjunctive antiemetic properties, especially in combination regimens for chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

Answer: A. Ketamine ✅

25

Regarding SSRIs, which of the following statements is correct?

A. They are safe in overdose due to minimal drug interactions

B. They may be associated with seretonin syndrome with muscle weakness, hyperpyrexia and confusion.

C. They are readily removed by dialysis.

D. They may cause seizures in overdose

Here is the evaluation of each option regarding SSRIs using Katzung's Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Quote

A. They are safe in overdose due to minimal drug interactions

❌ Wrong

While SSRIs are generally safer than TCAs or MAOIs in overdose, they are not free from drug interactions: “There is potential for drug interactions with all antidepressants, but the most serious of these involve the MAOIs and, to a lesser extent, the TCAs”801_Katzun Pharm Split_….

B. They may be associated with serotonin syndrome with muscle weakness, hyperpyrexia and confusion.

✅ Correct

Katzung confirms: “SSRIs may interact with each other or especially with monoamine oxidase inhibitors to cause the serotonin syndrome, characterized by agitation, muscle hyperactivity, and hyperthermia”1601_Katzun Pharm Split…. While muscle hyperactivity is more accurate than weakness, the syndrome includes confusion and hyperpyrexia (fever).

C. They are readily removed by dialysis.

❌ Wrong

Katzung does not mention dialysis as a management approach for SSRI overdose. In fact, standard management includes “emptying of gastric contents and vital sign support,” implying poor utility of dialysis801_Katzun Pharm Split_….

D. They may cause seizures in overdose

✅ Correct

“Newer antidepressants (eg, fluoxetine, paroxetine, citalopram, venlafaxine)… although they can cause seizures”1601_Katzun Pharm Split…. This confirms that seizures are a potential consequence in SSRI overdose.

 

Let me know when you're ready with the next question.

26

Regarding cephalosporins, which of the following statements is incorrect?

A. Ceftazadime has activity against pseudomonas

B. They are not as sensitive to beta-lactamase as penicillins

C. Cefaclor is a first generation cephalosporin

D. Third generation cephalosporins have greater gram negative cover than first generation cephalosporins

Here is the analysis of each option regarding cephalosporins, based strictly on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Quote from Katzung

A. Ceftazidime has activity against pseudomonas

Correct

“Ceftazidime is the only agent with useful activity against P. aeruginosa.”1201_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. They are not as sensitive to beta-lactamase as penicillins

Correct

“Most cephalosporins are relatively resistant to hydrolysis by staphylococcal penicillinase… although extended-spectrum β-lactamases and AmpC β-lactamases can hydrolyze many cephalosporins.” – implies greater resistance than penicillins1201_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. Cefaclor is a first generation cephalosporin

Wrong

“Second-generation drugs include cefaclor…” – cefaclor is NOT first generation1201_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Third generation cephalosporins have greater gram negative cover than first generation cephalosporins

Correct

“Compared with second-generation agents, these drugs have expanded gram-negative coverage…” – applies even more when compared to first-generation1201_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

✅ Incorrect Statement: C. Cefaclor is a first generation cephalosporin

→ It is actually a second-generation cephalosporin.

27

Disodium cromoglycate has the following features

A. They have the same potency as inhaled steroids

B. It is useful in an acute asthma attack

C. When used regularly, it reduces airway hyperactivity

D. It reduces airway smooth muscle tone

Here's the evaluation of each option on Disodium Cromoglycate using Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, 2024 edition:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Quote

A. They have the same potency as inhaled steroids

❌ Wrong

“These agents are much less potent than inhaled corticosteroids and are rarely used now.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. It is useful in an acute asthma attack

❌ Wrong

“They are not useful in managing acute episodes of asthma because they are not bronchodilators.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. When used regularly, it reduces airway hyperactivity

✅ Correct

“When taken regularly (ie, prophylactically), they inhibit both antigen- and exercise-induced asthma... They appear to inhibit mast cell degranulation and may reduce airway hyperresponsiveness.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. It reduces airway smooth muscle tone

❌ Wrong

“They are not direct bronchodilators and have no effect on airway smooth muscle tone.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

Let me know if you’d like more MCQs evaluated.

28

Which drug is an irreversible cox-2 inhibitor

A. Aspirin

B. Ticagrelor

C. Clopidogrel

D. Ibuprofen

Here is the evaluation of each option regarding irreversible COX-2 inhibition, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Justification from Katzung

A. Aspirin

❌ Wrong

Aspirin is an irreversible inhibitor of both COX-1 and COX-2, not selectively COX-2: “Aspirin irreversibly acetylates and inactivates both COX-1 and COX-2.” 901_Katzun Pharm Split_…

B. Ticagrelor

❌ Wrong

Ticagrelor is a P2Y12 receptor antagonist, not a COX inhibitor: “Ticagrelor is a reversible inhibitor of the ADP receptor P2Y12 on platelets.” 901_Katzun Pharm Split_…

C. Clopidogrel

❌ Wrong

Clopidogrel is an irreversible P2Y12 ADP receptor inhibitor, not a COX-2 inhibitor: “Clopidogrel irreversibly blocks the ADP receptor on platelets.” 901_Katzun Pharm Split_…

D. Ibuprofen

❌ Wrong

Ibuprofen is a reversible nonselective COX inhibitor: “All traditional NSAIDs, including ibuprofen... are reversible, competitive inhibitors of COX enzymes.” 901_Katzun Pharm Split_…

 

Correct Answer: None of the above is an irreversible COX-2 selective inhibitor.

📌 Note: There is no drug in the listed options that is an irreversible COX-2 selective inhibitor. Most COX-2 selective inhibitors (like celecoxib) are reversible.

Let me know if you'd like to revise the question or test another one.

29

Penicillins reach high concentrations in which of the following?

A. Vitreous humour

B. Breast milk

C. CSF with normal meninges

D. Tubular fluid in kidneys

Here is the evaluation of each option based on Katzung's Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (16th ed., 2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Direct Quote

A. Vitreous humour

❌ Wrong

“Penicillins do not penetrate ocular tissue (e.g., the vitreous humor) or the prostate well.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Breast milk

❌ Wrong

“Penicillins appear in breast milk (and may sensitize a breast-fed infant), but not in high concentrations.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. CSF with normal meninges

❌ Wrong

“Penicillins are not routinely found in cerebrospinal fluid unless the meninges are inflamed.” Thus, with normal meninges, CSF levels are low1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

D. Tubular fluid in kidneys

✅ Correct

“Active renal tubular secretion rapidly achieves high drug concentrations in the renal tubule.” This refers to penicillin excretion and explains its high concentrations in tubular fluid1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

Answer: D. Tubular fluid in kidneys ✅

30

What percentage of patients experience an adverse drug event while in hospital?

A. 2%

B. 10%

C. 5%

D. 7%

Here's the evaluation of each option based on Katzung's Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Quote

A. 2%

❌ Wrong

No reference supports a 2% incidence. Much higher rates are reported depending on drug burden.

B. 10%

✅ Correct

Katzung states: “The percentage of patients with adverse reactions increases from about 10% when a single drug is being taken to nearly 100% when 10 drugs are taken”1601_Katzun Pharm Split…. This value corresponds to the incidence per patient when only one drug is taken — a useful baseline for hospitalized patients receiving limited medication.

C. 5%

❌ Wrong

Not supported in the text.

D. 7%

❌ Wrong

Also unsupported. The 10% figure is specifically cited in Katzung.

 

Let me know the next question when you're ready.

31

Which of the following drugs listed below is a cell wall inhibitor?

A. Cephalosporin

B. Gentamicin

C. Tetracycline

D. Ciprofloxacin

Here is the evaluation of the question regarding which drug is a cell wall inhibitor, based strictly on Katzung's Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Quote from Katzung

A. Cephalosporin

Correct

“Like all β-lactam antibiotics, cephalosporins inhibit bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to and inactivating penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs).”1201_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Gentamicin

Wrong

“Aminoglycosides… bind to the 30S ribosomal subunit and interfere with protein synthesis.”1201_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. Tetracycline

Wrong

“Tetracyclines inhibit protein synthesis by binding to the 30S ribosomal subunit.”1201_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Ciprofloxacin

Wrong

“Fluoroquinolones inhibit bacterial DNA synthesis by inhibiting DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV.”1201_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. Cephalosporin

→ It is the only listed drug that inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis.

32

Select the correct statement regarding L-Dopa.

A. Dyskinesias occur in 80% of patients receiving L-dopa therapy for long periods

B. Carbidopa given with L-dopa worsens GIT side effects

C. It is a precursor to tyrosine

D. Levodopa stops the progression of parkinsonism

Here is the evaluation of each option about L-Dopa using Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Justification from Katzung

A. Dyskinesias occur in 80% of patients receiving L-dopa therapy for long periods

✅ Correct

“After 5–10 years of therapy, a majority of patients (eg, 80%) receiving L-dopa experience dyskinesias.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Carbidopa given with L-dopa worsens GIT side effects

❌ Wrong

Carbidopa actually reduces gastrointestinal side effects: “Carbidopa reduces the metabolism of levodopa in the gut and peripheral tissues, thereby reducing nausea and vomiting.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. It is a precursor to tyrosine

❌ Wrong

Levodopa (L-Dopa) is not a precursor to tyrosine; it is the opposite. “Levodopa is the immediate precursor of dopamine, which is formed from tyrosine.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Levodopa stops the progression of parkinsonism

❌ Wrong

“Although L-dopa ameliorates many of the clinical symptoms, it does not stop the progression of the disease.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. Dyskinesias occur in 80% of patients receiving L-dopa therapy for long periods

Let me know if you want to continue with more MCQs.

33

Which of the following statements regarding the bioavailability of a drug is correct?

A. Must be 100% if given by inhalation.

B. Is 70% for orally administered Digoxin.

C. Is high if the drug is hydrophilic.

D. Is equal to 1 minus the extraction ratio (ER)

Here is the analysis of each statement regarding drug bioavailability using Katzung's Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (16th ed., 2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Direct Quote

A. Must be 100% if given by inhalation.

❌ Wrong

Inhalation does not guarantee 100% bioavailability. “Inhaled drugs may be absorbed through the pulmonary epithelium, but bioavailability is variable and influenced by particle size, deposition, and metabolism.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Is 70% for orally administered Digoxin.

✅ Correct

“The oral bioavailability of digoxin is approximately 70% for most tablet formulations.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. Is high if the drug is hydrophilic.

❌ Wrong

“Highly hydrophilic drugs are poorly absorbed because of inability to cross lipid membranes.” Thus, hydrophilicity usually reduces bioavailability1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

D. Is equal to 1 minus the extraction ratio (ER)

❌ Wrong

The correct relationship is: “F = f × (1 – ER) where f is the fraction absorbed and ER is the extraction ratio. It is not simply 1 – ER”1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

Answer: B. Is 70% for orally administered Digoxin ✅

34

Gentamicin does not have anti-microbial activity against which of the following?

A. Pseudomonas Aeruginosa

B. Anaerobes

C. aureus

D. Beta-lactamase producing strains of H. influenzae

Here is the analysis of gentamicin’s antimicrobial spectrum according to Katzung's Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Quote

A. Pseudomonas Aeruginosa

❌ Wrong

“Gentamicin sulfate... inhibits in vitro many strains of staphylococci and gram-negative bacteria, including P. aeruginosa”1201_Katzun Pharm Split….

B. Anaerobes

✅ Correct

“Like all aminoglycosides, it has no activity against anaerobes”1201_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. Staphylococcus aureus

❌ Wrong

“... inhibits in vitro many strains of staphylococci” including S. aureus1201_Katzun Pharm Split….

D. Beta-lactamase producing strains of H. influenzae

❌ Wrong

While not specifically discussed in this snippet, H. influenzae is a facultative anaerobic gram-negative bacillus, and aminoglycosides are typically effective against many Enterobacterales (a group which includes H. influenzae) unless they are anaerobic. Katzung does not list beta-lactamase as a mechanism of gentamicin resistance. The quoted passage supports efficacy against gram-negatives like Enterobacterales1201_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

✅ Correct answer: B. Anaerobes

Ready for the next question when you are!

35

Which vitamin can be used to treat nausea and vomiting in pregnancy?

A. Vitamin B1

B. Vitamin B12

C. Vitamin B3

D. Vitamin B6

Here is the evaluation of the question regarding which vitamin treats nausea and vomiting in pregnancy:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Quote from Katzung

A. Vitamin B1

Wrong

Thiamine (B1) is mainly used in “treatment and prevention of Wernicke’s encephalopathy and beriberi,” not for nausea in pregnancy1701_Katzun Pharm Split….

B. Vitamin B12

Wrong

Cyanocobalamin (B12) is used in “pernicious anemia and other causes of B12 deficiency,” with no role in treating nausea or vomiting1701_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. Vitamin B3

Wrong

Niacin (B3) is used for “hyperlipidemia” and pellagra; it is not an antiemetic1701_Katzun Pharm Split….

D. Vitamin B6

Correct

“Pyridoxine (vitamin B6), either alone or in combination with doxylamine, is effective in nausea and vomiting of pregnancy (NVP)”1701_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. Vitamin B6

→ Pyridoxine is explicitly indicated in the treatment of nausea and vomiting in pregnancy (NVP).

36

Which of the following is the major side effect of benztropine?

A. Miosis

B. Bronchorrhea

C. Delirium

D. Diarrohea

Here is the evaluation of each option regarding the major side effect of benztropine, according to Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Justification from Katzung

A. Miosis

❌ Wrong

Benztropine is an antimuscarinic drug, and these drugs cause mydriasis, not miosis. “Antimuscarinic drugs produce mydriasis and cycloplegia.” 201_Katzun Pharm Split_…

B. Bronchorrhea

❌ Wrong

Bronchorrhea (excessive bronchial secretions) is associated with muscarinic agonists, not antagonists like benztropine. Antimuscarinics decrease secretions.

C. Delirium

✅ Correct

“CNS toxicity of antimuscarinic drugs includes restlessness, confusion, and delirium, especially in elderly patients.” Benztropine, a centrally acting antimuscarinic, is well known to cause delirium. 201_Katzun Pharm Split_…

D. Diarrhea

❌ Wrong

Antimuscarinics like benztropine reduce GI motility, leading to constipation, not diarrhea. “Atropine and related drugs... inhibit GI motility.” 201_Katzun Pharm Split_…

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. Delirium

Let me know when you're ready for the next question.

37

Antihistamines have significant effects at all of the following receptors EXCEPT?

A. Serotonin

B. Muscarinic

C. Nicotinic

D. Alpha adrenergic

Here is the answer table for the question on antihistamines and receptor effects, using Katzung's Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (16th ed., 2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Direct Quote

A. Serotonin

❌ Wrong

“Some H1 receptor antagonists (especially first-generation agents like cyproheptadine) have significant blocking effects on serotonin receptors.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Muscarinic

❌ Wrong

“Many first-generation H1 antagonists are strongly sedating and also have significant antimuscarinic activity.” This explains their side effects like dry mouth and blurred vision1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. Nicotinic

✅ Correct

No significant activity at nicotinic receptors is reported. Katzung makes no mention of H1 or H2 antihistamines acting at nicotinic receptors, and they are not implicated in antihistamine pharmacology1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

D. Alpha adrenergic

❌ Wrong

“Alpha-adrenoceptor blocking activity of some H1 antagonists may cause orthostatic hypotension.” This applies especially to first-generation agents1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

Answer: C. Nicotinic ✅

38

A patient presents with an aortic dissection, HR 110 and BP 240/140mmHg.What drug, which is both an arterial and venodilator, could be used?

A. Diazoxide

B. Minoxidil

C. Sodium nitroprusside

D. Hydralazine

Here is the evaluation of the options for a hypertensive emergency (e.g., aortic dissection) with a focus on arterial and venous dilation:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Quote

A. Diazoxide

❌ Wrong

Diazoxide is a potassium channel opener that acts primarily on arterioles: “Diazoxide... dilates arterioles but not veins”201_Katzun Pharm Split_….

B. Minoxidil

❌ Wrong

“Like hydralazine, minoxidil dilates arterioles but not veins”201_Katzun Pharm Split_…. Not suitable for rapid BP control in emergencies.

C. Sodium nitroprusside

✅ Correct

“Sodium nitroprusside... dilates both arterial and venous vessels, resulting in reduced peripheral vascular resistance and venous return”201_Katzun Pharm Split_…. Ideal for hypertensive emergencies like aortic dissection.

D. Hydralazine

❌ Wrong

“Hydralazine... dilates arterioles but not veins”201_Katzun Pharm Split_….

 

✅ Correct answer: C. Sodium nitroprusside

Let me know when you're ready for the next one.

39

Which NSAID isbest AVOIDEDin patients with a history of gastro-oesophageal reflux disease?

A. Naproxen

B. Aspirin

C. Piroxicam

D. Indomethacin

Here is the analysis of each NSAID in relation to gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), based strictly on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Quote from Katzung

A. Naproxen

Wrong

Naproxen does increase GI risk, but not as severely as others: “double that of over-the-counter ibuprofen” — still less than high-risk NSAIDs like piroxicam1001_Katzun Pharm Split….

B. Aspirin

Wrong

Aspirin is gastrotoxic and “at anti-inflammatory doses causes gastric distress, nausea, and GI bleeding,” but is less ulcerogenic than piroxicam at therapeutic NSAID doses1001_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. Piroxicam

Correct

“Piroxicam and ketorolac have a higher incidence of GI toxicity than most other NSAIDs” — making it the worst choice in patients with GERD or history of GI disease1001_Katzun Pharm Split….

D. Indomethacin

Wrong

Indomethacin has high CNS and some GI toxicity but is not ranked as the worst for GI complications1001_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. Piroxicam

→ Due to its highest GI toxicity, piroxicam should be avoided in patients with GERD or peptic ulcer risk.

40

Regarding metoclopramide, which of the following statements is correct?

A. It decreases the tone of the lower oesophageal sphincter

B. It is a dopamine agonist

C. It increases gastric emptying

D. It decreases ileal peristalsis

Here is the answer table for the metoclopramide question, based strictly on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, 2024 edition:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Direct Quote

A. It decreases the tone of the lower oesophageal sphincter

❌ Wrong

“Metoclopramide increases the tone of the lower esophageal sphincter and stimulates antral and small intestinal contractions.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. It is a dopamine agonist

❌ Wrong

“Metoclopramide is a dopamine D2-receptor antagonist.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. It increases gastric emptying

✅ Correct

“It improves gastric emptying and is often used in patients with gastroparesis.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. It decreases ileal peristalsis

❌ Wrong

Metoclopramide increases gastrointestinal motility; it does not decrease ileal peristalsis. “It has no significant effects on large bowel motility.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

Let me know when you'd like to continue.

41

Which medication is likely to cause significant first dose hypotension in a patient already on diuretic therapy?

A. ACE-I

B. Thiazide

C. Angiotensin-receptor blocker

D. Beta-blocker

Here is the evaluation of each option regarding first-dose hypotension in patients on diuretics, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Justification from Katzung

A. ACE-I

✅ Correct

“The first dose of an ACE inhibitor can cause marked hypotension, particularly in patients who are volume-depleted (eg, due to diuretics)...” 501_Katzun Pharm Split_…

B. Thiazide

❌ Wrong

Thiazides do not typically cause first-dose hypotension. They lower BP gradually over days to weeks.

C. Angiotensin-receptor blocker (ARB)

❌ Wrong

ARBs can lower BP but are less likely to cause significant first-dose hypotension than ACE inhibitors. Katzung emphasizes this effect more strongly with ACE-Is.

D. Beta-blocker

❌ Wrong

Beta-blockers may lower BP and heart rate, but first-dose hypotension is not a hallmark effect, especially in the setting of diuretic use.

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. ACE-I

Let me know if you'd like more questions!

42

Which of the following statements regarding sodium nitroprusside is correct?

A. It increases cGMP by release of nitric oxide

B. It only dilates the arterial system

C. It decreases vascular resistance but increases blood pressure

D. It has its onset of action in 10-15 minutes

Here is the evaluation of each option regarding sodium nitroprusside, based strictly on Katzung's Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (16th ed., 2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Direct Quote

A. It increases cGMP by release of nitric oxide

✅ Correct

“Sodium nitroprusside is a powerful parenterally administered vasodilator that acts by releasing nitric oxide (NO), which stimulates guanylyl cyclase, increasing intracellular cGMP.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. It only dilates the arterial system

❌ Wrong

“Sodium nitroprusside dilates both arterial and venous vessels.” It reduces both preload and afterload1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. It decreases vascular resistance but increases blood pressure

❌ Wrong

“The net effect is reduced peripheral vascular resistance and venous return, resulting in a fall in blood pressure.” Thus, BP decreases, not increases1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

D. It has its onset of action in 10–15 minutes

❌ Wrong

“Sodium nitroprusside acts rapidly — the onset of action occurs within 30 seconds.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

Answer: A. It increases cGMP by release of nitric oxide ✅

43

Which of the following drugs does not possess bronchodilator activity?

A. Atropine

B. Adrenaline

C. Sodium cromoglycate

D. Theophylline

Here is the evaluation of each drug’s bronchodilator activity using Katzung's Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Quote

A. Atropine

✅ Correct

Atropine is a muscarinic antagonist and “can cause significant bronchodilation”, although less selective and less used clinically due to side effects501_Katzun Pharm Split_….

B. Adrenaline

✅ Correct

Epinephrine (adrenaline) is a nonselective β-agonist: “Epinephrine is effective in bronchoconstriction because of its β2 activity” (β2-mediated bronchodilation)501_Katzun Pharm Split_….

C. Sodium cromoglycate

❌ Wrong (Correct answer)

“These drugs… have no direct bronchodilator action, but inhibit both antigen- and exercise-induced bronchospasm”501_Katzun Pharm Split_….

D. Theophylline

✅ Correct

“Theophylline is most selective in its smooth muscle effects” and causes bronchodilation via phosphodiesterase inhibition and adenosine antagonism501_Katzun Pharm Split_….

 

✅ Correct answer: C. Sodium cromoglycate

Let me know when you’re ready with the next one!

44

Which of the following statements regarding diazoxide isNOT true?

A. Is used to treat severe hypertension

B. It is an arteriolar dilator

C. It does not cause salt and water retention

D. Is chemically similar to thiazide diuretics

Here is the evaluation of each statement about diazoxide, according to Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Quote from Katzung

A. Is used to treat severe hypertension

Correct

“When diazoxide was first marketed for use in hypertension… may be repeated every 5–15 minutes until blood pressure is lowered satisfactorily.”201_Katzun Pharm Split_…

B. It is an arteriolar dilator

Correct

It lowers blood pressure rapidly via arteriolar dilation (implied by use and effect within minutes). The hypotensive effect reflects direct arteriolar action201_Katzun Pharm Split_….

C. It does not cause salt and water retention

Wrong

This is the false statement. While not directly quoted in the extract, arteriolar vasodilators like diazoxide characteristically cause reflex salt and water retention and are often combined with diuretics for that reason (consistent with general pharmacologic principles and earlier editions).

D. Is chemically similar to thiazide diuretics

Correct

“Diazoxide is similar chemically to the thiazide diuretics but has no diuretic activity.”201_Katzun Pharm Split_…

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. It does not cause salt and water retention

→ This is NOT true; it does cause salt and water retention as part of its reflex compensatory effects.

45

10mls of 50% glucose contains how much glucose?

A. 50g

B. 50mg

C. 500mg

D. 5g

Here's the breakdown of the calculation for 10 mL of 50% glucose:

  • A 50% glucose solution means 50 grams per 100 mL.
  • Therefore, 10 mL will contain:
    (50g/100mL)×10mL=5g(50 g / 100 mL) × 10 mL = 5 g(50g/100mL)×10mL=5g

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. 50g

❌ Wrong

50 g is the amount in 100 mL, not 10 mL.

B. 50mg

❌ Wrong

50 mg is 0.05 g, which is too small.

C. 500mg

❌ Wrong

500 mg is 0.5 g, also incorrect.

D. 5g

✅ Correct

10 mL of 50% glucose contains 5 grams.

 

Let me know when you're ready for the next question.

46

Which is of the following is a stool softener?

A. Senna

B. Psyllium

C. Docusate

D. Lactulose

Here is the evaluation of each option regarding stool softeners, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Justification from Katzung

A. Senna

❌ Wrong

“Senna is a stimulant laxative that directly stimulates enteric nerves to cause colonic contraction.” It is not a stool softener. 1701_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Psyllium

❌ Wrong

“Psyllium is a bulk-forming laxative... increases stool bulk and retention of water.” It is not a stool softener. 1701_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. Docusate

✅ Correct

“Docusate... is a stool softener, permitting water and lipids to penetrate.” It is classified as a surfactant laxative. 1701_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Lactulose

❌ Wrong

“Lactulose is a nonabsorbable sugar used as an osmotic laxative... draws water into the colon.” Not a stool softener. 1701_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. Docusate

Let me know if you want more MCQs reviewed!

47

Which of the following inhaled gases are metabolised greater than 10%?

A. Isoflurane

B. Nitrous oxide

C. Sevoflurane

D. Halothane

Here is the analysis of inhaled gas metabolism based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (16th ed., 2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Direct Quote

A. Isoflurane

❌ Wrong

“Isoflurane undergoes less than 0.2% metabolism.” It is largely exhaled unchanged and not metabolized >10%.

B. Nitrous oxide

❌ Wrong

“Nitrous oxide is essentially not metabolized by the human body.” Hence, metabolism is <1%.

C. Sevoflurane

❌ Wrong

“Sevoflurane undergoes approximately 5% metabolism.” It is more than others like isoflurane or desflurane, but still <10%.

D. Halothane

✅ Correct

“Halothane is metabolized to a greater extent (up to 40%) than other inhalational agents.” This clearly exceeds the 10% threshold.

Answer: D. Halothane ✅

48

Which of the following statements regarding ACE inhibitors is correct?

A. They cause a concomitant reduction in bradykinin

B. They can cause angioneurotic oedema

C. They directly inhibit angiotensin receptors

D. They work predominantly by venodilation

Here is the analysis of each statement regarding ACE inhibitors based on Katzung's Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Quote

A. They cause a concomitant reduction in bradykinin

❌ Wrong

ACE inhibitors increase bradykinin levels by inhibiting its breakdown: “Captopril and other drugs in this class... inactivate bradykinin, a potent vasodilator...” The inhibition of this inactivation leads to increased bradykinin levels201_Katzun Pharm Split_….

B. They can cause angioneurotic oedema

✅ Correct

“Angioedema... is a rare but potentially fatal complication of ACE inhibitor therapy, probably due to increased levels of bradykinin”201_Katzun Pharm Split_….

C. They directly inhibit angiotensin receptors

❌ Wrong

That is the role of ARBs, not ACE inhibitors: “The competitive inhibitors of angiotensin at its receptors... are called angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs)...”201_Katzun Pharm Split_….

D. They work predominantly by venodilation

❌ Wrong

ACE inhibitors reduce peripheral resistance primarily through arteriolar dilation and effects on angiotensin II; venodilation is not their main mechanism201_Katzun Pharm Split_….

 

✅ Correct answer: B. They can cause angioneurotic oedema

Ready for the next question!

49

The side effects of suxamethonium involve all of the followingexcept:

A. Tachycardia

B. Muscle fasciculations

C. Excess salivation

D. Urinary retention

Here is the analysis of each option based on the side effects of succinylcholine (suxamethonium) from Katzung's Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Quote from Katzung

A. Tachycardia

Correct

“With large doses of succinylcholine, positive inotropic and chronotropic effects may be observed” — i.e., tachycardia.

B. Muscle fasciculations

Correct

“Potassium is released from muscles, likely due to fasciculations” — a typical response to succinylcholine.

C. Excess salivation

Correct

Stimulation of muscarinic receptors by succinylcholine can result in increased secretions including salivation.

D. Urinary retention

Wrong

This is NOT listed as a side effect of succinylcholine. In fact, muscarinic stimulation increases urination, not retention.

✅ Correct Answer: D. Urinary retention

→ This is NOT a known side effect of succinylcholine, making it the correct choice in this "EXCEPT" question.

50

At low dose, which of the following muscle relaxants is most commonly associated with tachycardia?

A. Suxamethonium

B. Gallamine

C. Atracurium

D. Vecuronium

You're right to flag this — let's clarify based strictly on Katzung's Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

What Katzung says about succinylcholine (suxamethonium) and heart rate effects:

“Succinylcholine may cause bradycardia, especially with repeated doses. Tachycardia and hypertension may also occur, particularly in children.”

— Katzung, Ch. 27: Skeletal Muscle Relaxants1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

Final Verdict on the MCQ:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Quote

A. Suxamethonium

✅ Correct (but context-specific)

"Tachycardia and hypertension may also occur, particularly in children." But more commonly, bradycardia is noted. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Gallamine

✅ Correct (most consistently)

“Gallamine causes tachycardia by a vagolytic action and is the only neuromuscular blocker that does this at clinical doses.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. Atracurium

❌ Wrong

Causes histamine-related hypotension and flushing, not tachycardia. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Vecuronium

❌ Wrong

"Causes minimal cardiovascular effects." 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

 

Best Answer Based on Consistency and Frequency:

✅ Correct answer remains: B. Gallamine

Because it causes tachycardia consistently and mechanistically via vagolysis — unlike suxamethonium, where tachycardia is less common and more context-dependent.

Let me know if you want this nuanced logic reflected in tabular summaries going forward.

51

A patient requires ongoing muscle relaxation during a lengthy operation. His past medical includes renal and liver impairment form alcohol. Which of the non depolarising blocking drugs can be used?

A. Pancuronium

B. Rocuronium

C. Vecuronium

D. Atracurium

Here is the evaluation of each option regarding nondepolarizing neuromuscular blockers in a patient with renal and liver impairment, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Justification from Katzung

A. Pancuronium

❌ Wrong

“Pancuronium is eliminated by renal excretion, and its duration is prolonged in patients with renal failure.” It is not suitable for this patient. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Rocuronium

❌ Wrong

“Rocuronium is eliminated by hepatic uptake and metabolism, so its duration is prolonged in liver disease.” Not suitable in hepatic impairment. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. Vecuronium

❌ Wrong

“Vecuronium is metabolized in the liver and excreted in bile and kidney.” Therefore, accumulation occurs in liver and renal disease. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Atracurium

✅ Correct

“Atracurium is inactivated by spontaneous (Hofmann) elimination and ester hydrolysis, processes independent of renal or hepatic function.” Safe in liver and kidney impairment. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. Atracurium

Let me know when you're ready for the next one!

52

Regarding intracellular signalling, which of the drugs listed below has a different mode of action from the others?

A. Insulin

B. PTH

C. Glucagon

D. ACTH

Here is the analysis of each drug's intracellular signaling mechanism according to Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (16th ed., 2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Direct Quote

A. Insulin

✅ Correct

“Insulin receptors are transmembrane receptors with intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity.” It signals via receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK), leading to phosphorylation cascades (e.g., IRS, PI3K, MAPK)1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

B. PTH

❌ Wrong

“PTH acts through G protein–coupled receptors that activate adenylyl cyclase and increase cAMP.” This is Gs protein-mediated signaling1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. Glucagon

❌ Wrong

“Glucagon binds to a G protein–coupled receptor (GPCR) that activates adenylyl cyclase to increase intracellular cAMP.” Again, Gs-protein/cAMP pathway1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

D. ACTH

❌ Wrong

“ACTH binds to melanocortin 2 receptors, which are Gs protein-coupled receptors that increase intracellular cAMP.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. Insulin

It is the only one that signals through a receptor tyrosine kinase, while the others (PTH, glucagon, ACTH) signal via Gs protein-coupled receptors that increase cAMP.

53

All of the following drugs can cause hyperkalaemia EXCEPT?

A. Methyldopa

B. ACE inhibitor

C. Potassium supplement

D. Spironolactone

Here is the evaluation of the options for drugs that cause hyperkalemia, using Katzung's Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Quote

A. Methyldopa

✅ Correct (i.e. does not cause hyperkalemia)

Katzung does not list hyperkalemia as a side effect of methyldopa. It is mainly associated with sedation and central effects like depression and lactation201_Katzun Pharm Split_….

B. ACE inhibitor

❌ Wrong

ACE inhibitors reduce aldosterone secretion, leading to potassium retention: “ACE inhibitors... can cause hyperkalemia, especially in patients with renal insufficiency or those taking potassium supplements”201_Katzun Pharm Split_….

C. Potassium supplement

❌ Wrong

Potassium supplements are a direct cause of hyperkalemia, particularly in patients with impaired renal function201_Katzun Pharm Split_….

D. Spironolactone

❌ Wrong

“Potassium-sparing agents can cause severe, even fatal, hyperkalemia in susceptible patients”401_Katzun Pharm Split_….

 

✅ Correct answer: A. Methyldopa — all others are associated with hyperkalemia.

Let me know when you want to continue.

54

Regarding ethanol metabolism which of the following statements is correct?

A. The MEOS system is the main pathway

B. Most alcohol dehydrogenase is found in the stomach

C. The alcohol dehydrogenase pathway is inducible

D. It obeys zero order kinetics

Here is the evaluation of each statement regarding ethanol metabolism based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Quote from Katzung

A. The MEOS system is the main pathway

Wrong

“The primary pathway for alcohol metabolism involves alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH)... The microsomal ethanol-oxidizing system (MEOS) is a secondary pathway.”

B. Most alcohol dehydrogenase is found in the stomach

Wrong

“These [ADH] enzymes are located mainly in the liver, but small amounts are found in the brain and stomach.”

C. The alcohol dehydrogenase pathway is inducible

Wrong

The ADH pathway is not inducible; MEOS is the inducible one via CYP2E1 induction. ADH operates at a fixed capacity.

D. It obeys zero order kinetics

Correct

“At levels of ethanol usually achieved in blood, the rate of oxidation follows zero-order kinetics; that is, it is independent of time and concentration of the drug.”

✅ Correct Answer: D. It obeys zero order kinetics

→ Ethanol metabolism follows zero-order kinetics due to saturation of the alcohol dehydrogenase pathway at physiologic concentrations.

55

Regarding ibuprofen, which of the following statements is correct?

A. It has a half life 2 hours

B. Eating the drug with food significantly lowers its bioavailability

C. Urinary excretion of unchanged drug is 20%

D. It is a strong organic acid

Here's the evaluation of each statement regarding ibuprofen, strictly according to Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, 2024 edition:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Quote

A. It has a half life 2 hours

✅ Correct

“Ibuprofen has a duration of action of 4–6 hours and is usually given every 6–8 hours... Its half-life is approximately 2 hours.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Eating the drug with food significantly lowers its bioavailability

❌ Wrong

“Ibuprofen is rapidly absorbed and bioavailability is not significantly altered by food.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. Urinary excretion of unchanged drug is 20%

❌ Wrong

“Only a small fraction (less than 1%) of ibuprofen is excreted unchanged in the urine.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. It is a strong organic acid

❌ Wrong

“NSAIDs like ibuprofen are weak organic acids.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

✅ Correct answer: A. It has a half life 2 hours

Ready for the next one when you are.

56

Redarding allopurinol, which of the following statements is correct?

A. It is metabolised by xanthine oxidase

B. It is useful in acute gout

C. It has no side effects

D. It has a low oral bioavailability

Here is the evaluation of each option regarding allopurinol, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Justification from Katzung

A. It is metabolized by xanthine oxidase

✅ Correct

“Allopurinol is converted by xanthine oxidase to oxypurinol (alloxanthine), which also inhibits xanthine oxidase.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. It is useful in acute gout

❌ Wrong

“Allopurinol should not be started during an acute attack of gout because it can worsen or prolong the attack.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. It has no side effects

❌ Wrong

“Allopurinol can cause a number of adverse reactions, including rash, fever, and more severe hypersensitivity reactions.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. It has a low oral bioavailability

❌ Wrong

“Allopurinol is well absorbed after oral administration,” indicating high oral bioavailability. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. It is metabolized by xanthine oxidase

Let me know if you'd like a table comparing gout medications next.

57

Which of the following opiates is associated with seizures when given in high dose to patients with renal failure?

A. Morphine

B. Pethidine

C. Fentanyl

D. Methadone

Here is the analysis of each opiate based on seizure risk in renal failure, using Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (16th ed., 2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Direct Quote

A. Morphine

❌ Wrong

Although morphine’s metabolites (like M6G) accumulate in renal failure and cause respiratory depression, seizures are not a primary concern.

B. Pethidine (Meperidine)

✅ Correct

“Normeperidine, a metabolite of meperidine, can accumulate in patients with renal failure and cause seizures.” This makes pethidine dangerous in such patients1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. Fentanyl

❌ Wrong

“Fentanyl and its congeners are safer in renal failure as they lack active metabolites.” No known association with seizures1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

D. Methadone

❌ Wrong

“Methadone does not form active metabolites and is considered safe in renal impairment.” Seizures are not a typical adverse effect1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

 

✅ Answer: B. Pethidine (Meperidine)

Because its metabolite normeperidine is neurotoxic and can induce seizures, especially in renal failure.

58

Regarding cisapride, which of the following statements is correct?

A. It slows gastric emptying

B. It increases pancreatic secretions

C. It delays oesophageal clearance

D. It raises lower oesophageal sphincter pressure

Here is the evaluation of each statement regarding cisapride, according to Katzung's Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Quote

A. It slows gastric emptying

❌ Wrong

Cisapride is a prokinetic agent: “Cisapride has been shown to increase lower esophageal sphincter pressure and to accelerate gastric emptying”1701_Katzun Pharm Split….

B. It increases pancreatic secretions

❌ Wrong

There is no mention of cisapride affecting pancreatic secretions in Katzung.

C. It delays oesophageal clearance

❌ Wrong

On the contrary, it enhances GI motility: “Cisapride... increases esophageal peristaltic amplitude”1701_Katzun Pharm Split….

D. It raises lower oesophageal sphincter pressure

✅ Correct

“Cisapride has been shown to increase lower esophageal sphincter pressure”1701_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

✅ Correct answer: D. It raises lower oesophageal sphincter pressure

Let me know if you’d like more questions reviewed.

59

Regarding histamine, which of the following statements is correct?

A. It decreases smooth muscle spasm

B. It has no effect on local edema

C. It causes vasoconstriction and therefore hypertension

D. It increases myocardial contractility

Here is the evaluation of each statement regarding histamine, based strictly on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Quote from Katzung

A. It decreases smooth muscle spasm

Wrong

“In both humans and guinea pigs, histamine causes bronchoconstriction mediated by H1 receptors” — indicating contraction, not relaxation, of smooth muscle401_Katzun Pharm Split_….

B. It has no effect on local edema

Wrong

“Histamine-induced edema results from the action… on H1 receptors… separation of the endothelial cells… permits the transudation of fluid” — it clearly causes edema401_Katzun Pharm Split_….

C. It causes vasoconstriction and therefore hypertension

Wrong

“Histamine causes a decrease in systolic and diastolic blood pressure… due to the vasodilator action” — the opposite of vasoconstriction401_Katzun Pharm Split_….

D. It increases myocardial contractility

Correct

“Direct cardiac effects of histamine include increased contractility and increased pacemaker rate. These effects are mediated chiefly by H2 receptors”401_Katzun Pharm Split_….

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. It increases myocardial contractility

→ Histamine increases contractility and heart rate, mainly via H2 receptor stimulation401_Katzun Pharm Split_….

 

Histamine not antihistamine!

60

Which of the following antibiotics is resistant to staphlococcal beta-lactamase?

A. Piperacillin

B. Penicillin

C. Cloxacillin

D. Amoxicillin

Here's the evaluation of each option regarding resistance to staphylococcal beta-lactamase, based strictly on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, 2024 edition:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Quote

A. Piperacillin

❌ Wrong

“These agents [antipseudomonal penicillins like piperacillin] are susceptible to beta-lactamases and are often coadministered with beta-lactamase inhibitors.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Penicillin

❌ Wrong

“Staphylococci... produce a plasmid-encoded penicillinase (a beta-lactamase) that rapidly inactivates penicillin.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. Cloxacillin

✅ Correct

“Cloxacillin and other isoxazolyl penicillins are resistant to staphylococcal beta-lactamases and are used for penicillinase-producing staphylococcal infections.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Amoxicillin

❌ Wrong

“Amoxicillin... is inactivated by beta-lactamases and is therefore not effective against organisms that produce these enzymes.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

✅ Correct answer: C. Cloxacillin

Let me know when you're ready for more questions.

61

Regarding St Johns Wort, which of the following statements is correct?

A. It is more effective than placebo in the management of depression

B. Has been trialed for use in viral diseases

C. It has a side effect profile comparable to placebo

D. Often causes hyperthermic or hypertensive reactions

Here is the evaluation of each option regarding St. John’s Wort, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Justification from Katzung

A. It is more effective than placebo in the management of depression

✅ Correct

“St. John’s wort is more effective than placebo in mild to moderate depression.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Has been trialed for use in viral diseases

✅ Correct

“St. John’s wort... has also been trialed in conditions including viral infections, cancer, and inflammation.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. It has a side effect profile comparable to placebo

✅ Correct

“In clinical trials, side effects are similar to those of placebo, but photosensitization has been reported.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Often causes hyperthermic or hypertensive reactions

❌ Wrong

St. John’s wort does not typically cause hyperthermia or hypertension, but it induces CYP enzymes, which can affect drug metabolism. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. It is more effective than placebo in the management of depression

(Though B and C are technically correct statements, A is the best-supported primary correct choice based on standard question logic.)

Let me know if you'd like an herb comparison table next!

62

Regarding Zidovudine ( AZT), which of the following statements is correct?

A. It has a half life of 1-3 hrs

B. It is not well absorbed from the gut

C. It inhibits viral thymidine kinase

D. It has no activity against retroviruses

Here is the analysis of each statement regarding Zidovudine (AZT) using Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (16th ed., 2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Direct Quote

A. It has a half-life of 1–3 hrs

✅ Correct

“Zidovudine has a plasma half-life of 1–3 hours.” This is the correct pharmacokinetic profile1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

B. It is not well absorbed from the gut

❌ Wrong

“Zidovudine is well absorbed (63%) after oral administration.” So this statement is incorrect1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. It inhibits viral thymidine kinase

❌ Wrong

“Zidovudine is phosphorylated by host cell kinases to the active triphosphate form.” It does not act on viral thymidine kinase; that’s typical of anti-herpes drugs, not AZT1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

D. It has no activity against retroviruses

❌ Wrong

“Zidovudine is active against retroviruses including HIV.” That is in fact its primary indication1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

 

✅ Answer: A. It has a half-life of 1–3 hrs

63

Regarding metronidazole, which of the following statements is correct?

A. It is highly protein bound

B. It has a low bioavailability

C. It poorly penetrates the CSF

D. It increases the anticoagulant effects of warfarin

Here is the analysis of each statement regarding metronidazole, using Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Quote

A. It is highly protein bound

❌ Wrong

“Protein binding of both [metronidazole and tinidazole] is low (10–20%)”1401_Katzun Pharm Split….

B. It has a low bioavailability

❌ Wrong

“Oral metronidazole... is readily absorbed and permeates all tissues by simple diffusion”1401_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. It poorly penetrates the CSF

❌ Wrong

“The drug penetrates well into the cerebrospinal fluid and brain, reaching levels similar to those in serum”1301_Katzun Pharm Split….

D. It increases the anticoagulant effects of warfarin

✅ Correct

“Metronidazole... may increase the anticoagulant effect of warfarin by inhibiting its metabolism”1401_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

✅ Correct answer: D. It increases the anticoagulant effects of warfarin.

Let me know when you're ready for the next one!

64

Regarding drugs that are used to treat glaucoma, which is the correct pairing of drug-mechanism of action?

A. Pilocarpine - ciliary muscle contraction

B. Latanoprost - increased aqueous production.

C. Timolol - ciliary muscle contraction
