✅ Correct answer: A. Hydroxylation, conjugation with glucuronides, urinary excretion

Let me know if you'd like a chart of benzodiazepines classified by half-life and metabolism.

366

Regarding therapeutic index, which of the following statements is correct?

A. It is the ratio of ED50/LD50

B. Potent drugs are more likely to have a high therapeutic index.

C. It is the ratio of TD50/ED50

D. High therapeutic index means a drug is dangerous

Here is the evaluation of each option regarding the therapeutic index (TI), based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Justification from Katzung

A. It is the ratio of ED₅₀/LD₅₀

❌ Wrong

The therapeutic index is the ratio of LD₅₀ to ED₅₀, not the other way around. A higher LD₅₀ compared to ED₅₀ indicates greater safety. 【Katzung Ch. 2†】

B. Potent drugs are more likely to have a high therapeutic index

❌ Wrong

Potency is not related to safety. A drug can be very potent (effective at low dose) but still have a narrow therapeutic index (i.e., dangerous). TI is about safety, not potency. 【Katzung Ch. 2†】

C. It is the ratio of TD₅₀/ED₅₀

✅ Correct

“The therapeutic index is defined as TD₅₀/ED₅₀, where TD₅₀ is the median toxic dose and ED₅₀ is the median effective dose.” This is a measure of drug safety. 【Katzung Ch. 2†】

D. High therapeutic index means a drug is dangerous

❌ Wrong

A high therapeutic index means the drug has a wide safety margin—so it is safer, not more dangerous. 【Katzung Ch. 2†】

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. It is the ratio of TD₅₀/ED₅₀

Let me know if you’d like a visual on therapeutic index and safety margins across drug classes.

367

A 50-year-old man has develops increasing size of his joints, deepening of his voice and a change in shoe size over the past six months. Which medication is most likely to be effective in treating his condition?

A. Octreotide

B. Cortisol

C. Insulin

D. Glucagon

Here is the evaluation of each option based on the likely diagnosis and pharmacologic treatment, using Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (16th ed., 2024):

 

🧠 Clinical Scenario Suggests: Acromegaly

  • Symptoms like enlarged joints, deep voice, and increased shoe size are classic for excess growth hormone (GH), typically due to a pituitary adenoma.
  • Treatment targets GH suppression or blockade of its effects.

 

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. Octreotide

✅ Correct

“Octreotide is a long-acting somatostatin analog that inhibits growth hormone release from the pituitary.” It is the first-line medical therapy for acromegaly1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

B. Cortisol

❌ Wrong

Cortisol has no role in treating acromegaly. It’s used in adrenal insufficiency or inflammatory states, not GH excess1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. Insulin

❌ Wrong

Insulin is used in diabetes mellitus, not in the management of acromegaly. GH may cause insulin resistance, but insulin does not treat GH excess1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

D. Glucagon

❌ Wrong

Glucagon raises blood glucose and is not relevant to GH suppression or acromegaly treatment1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

 

✅ Answer: A. Octreotide

Octreotide, a somatostatin analog, effectively suppresses growth hormone secretion and is the preferred pharmacologic treatment for acromegaly.

368

Which of the following opioids have only INACTIVE metabolites?

A. Oxycodone

B. Codeine

C. Morphine

D. Methadone

Here is the comparison of opioid metabolism regarding active vs. inactive metabolites, based strictly on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. Oxycodone

❌ Wrong

Oxycodone is metabolized to oxymorphone, which is active. Although the parent drug is mainly responsible for the effect, active metabolites do exist801_Katzun Pharm Split_….

B. Codeine

❌ Wrong

Codeine is metabolized by CYP2D6 to morphine, which is an active metabolite with most of the analgesic effect801_Katzun Pharm Split_….

C. Morphine

❌ Wrong

Morphine is metabolized to M3G (inactive but excitatory) and M6G, which is active and 4–6 times more potent than morphine itself801_Katzun Pharm Split_….

D. Methadone

✅ Correct

Methadone is metabolized via multiple CYP450 pathways, but does not form active metabolites contributing to opioid activity801_Katzun Pharm Split_….

 

✅ Correct answer: D. Methadone — It is the only listed opioid with only inactive metabolites.

369

Which of the following statements regarding carbamazepine is correct?

A. Overdose causes seizures

B. Sodium valproate increases carbamazepine clearance

C. It is an enzyme inhibitor

D. It metabolises to non-active metabolites.

Here is the evaluation of each statement about carbamazepine, with direct references from Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. Overdose causes seizures

✅ Correct

While not detailed explicitly in Katzung, carbamazepine toxicity is known to cause CNS excitation and seizures, especially in overdose. This is supported by clinical evidence.

B. Sodium valproate increases carbamazepine clearance

❌ Wrong

Katzung states that valproate may inhibit carbamazepine clearance and increase its blood levels: "Valproate may inhibit carbamazepine clearance and increase steady-state carbamazepine blood levels."601_Katzun Pharm Split_….

C. It is an enzyme inhibitor

❌ Wrong

Katzung clearly states: "Carbamazepine stimulates the transcriptional up-regulation of CYP3A4 and CYP2B6..." — i.e., it is an enzyme inducer, not an inhibitor601_Katzun Pharm Split_….

D. It metabolises to non-active metabolites

❌ Wrong

Carbamazepine has an active metabolite, carbamazepine-10,11-epoxide, whose levels may increase in the presence of valproate601_Katzun Pharm Split_….

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. Overdose causes seizures

All other options are refuted by Katzung 2024. Let me know if you want a table summarizing all carbamazepine interactions or toxicities.

370

Which class of UTI antibiotics affects the P450 sytem

A. Fluoroquinolones

B. Nitrofurantoin

C. Trimethoprim

D. Amoxicillin

Here is the evaluation of each urinary tract infection (UTI) antibiotic regarding cytochrome P450 interaction, based strictly on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, 2024 edition:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Quote

A. Fluoroquinolones

✅ Correct

“Some fluoroquinolones (especially ciprofloxacin) can inhibit cytochrome P450 enzymes, particularly CYP1A2, leading to elevated levels of drugs like theophylline and caffeine.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Nitrofurantoin

❌ Wrong

Nitrofurantoin is rapidly excreted in urine and does not significantly affect the P450 system. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. Trimethoprim

❌ Wrong

Trimethoprim may affect renal creatinine handling but has minimal interaction with the P450 system. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Amoxicillin

❌ Wrong

Amoxicillin is not known to induce or inhibit cytochrome P450 enzymes. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

✅ Correct answer: A. Fluoroquinolones

Let me know if you'd like a table of common antibiotics with their P450 interactions and adverse effects.

371

The anti-hypertensive effects of clonidine occur due to

A. Beta receptor blockade

B. Alpha 2 receptor activation

C. Ganglion blocking agents

D. Alpha 1 receptor blockade

Here is the evaluation of each option regarding the mechanism of clonidine's antihypertensive effect, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Justification from Katzung

A. Beta receptor blockade

❌ Wrong

Clonidine does not block beta receptors. Beta blockers like propranolol lower BP via different mechanisms. Clonidine acts centrally, not via beta blockade.

B. Alpha-2 receptor activation

✅ Correct

“Clonidine is a centrally acting alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that decreases sympathetic outflow from the CNS, reducing heart rate and blood pressure.” This is the primary antihypertensive mechanism. 【Katzung Ch. 11†】

C. Ganglion blocking agents

❌ Wrong

Clonidine is not a ganglionic blocker. Drugs like hexamethonium act at autonomic ganglia, not centrally like clonidine.

D. Alpha-1 receptor blockade

❌ Wrong

Alpha-1 blockers (e.g., prazosin) act peripherally to reduce vascular tone. Clonidine does not block alpha-1 receptors.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Alpha-2 receptor activation

Let me know if you'd like a table comparing mechanisms of different antihypertensive drug classes.

372

Atropine

A. Is a quaternary ammonium compound

B. It is predominantly metabolised by the liver

C. Its mydriatic action lasts 12-24hrs

D. It may cause bradycardia

Here is the evaluation of each statement regarding atropine, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (16th ed., 2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. Is a quaternary ammonium compound

❌ Wrong

“Atropine is a tertiary amine alkaloid.” It readily crosses the blood-brain barrier, unlike quaternary compounds which are more polar1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

B. It is predominantly metabolised by the liver

✅ Correct

“Atropine is metabolized in the liver and excreted in the urine.” Therefore, hepatic metabolism is predominant1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. Its mydriatic action lasts 12–24 hrs

❌ Wrong

“Atropine’s mydriatic effect can last 7–10 days due to its strong muscarinic blockade in the eye.” Much longer than 12–24 hrs1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

D. It may cause bradycardia

❌ Wrong

“Atropine may cause transient bradycardia at very low doses (by blocking presynaptic M1 receptors), but at therapeutic doses it causes tachycardia by blocking cardiac M2 receptors.” So overall effect is not bradycardia1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

 

✅ Answer: B. It is predominantly metabolised by the liver

This is the correct statement — atropine is a tertiary amine that is primarily metabolized in the liver.

373

Calculate the half life of Digoxin in a 70 kg patient with a renal clearance of 9L/h and volume distribution of 500 L/70kg

A. 28 hours

B. 32 hours

C. 39 hours

D. 44 hours

The calculated half-life of Digoxin in this 70 kg patient is:

✅ 38.5 hours

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. 28 hours

❌ Wrong

Underestimates the calculated value.

B. 32 hours

❌ Wrong

Slightly below the correct value.

C. 39 hours

✅ Correct

Closest to the calculated value of 38.5 hours.

D. 44 hours

❌ Wrong

Overestimates the value.

 

✅ Correct answer: C. 39 hours

Let me know if you'd like a reference table for calculating half-lives from Vd and clearance!

374

A 70kg man is commenced on a medication. What is the half life of this medication given a volume of distribution of 500L, and a clearance of 12L/hour?

A. 24 hours

B. 39 hours

C. 29 hours

D. 34 hours

To calculate the half-life (t½) of a drug, we use the standard pharmacokinetic formula:

t1/2=0.693×VdCLt_{1/2} = \frac{0.693 \times V_d}{CL}t1/2​=CL0.693×Vd​​

 

🔢 Given:

  • Volume of distribution (Vd) = 500 L
  • Clearance (CL) = 12 L/hour

t1/2=0.693×50012=346.512≈28.88 hours≈29 hourst_{1/2} = \frac{0.693 \times 500}{12} = \frac{346.5}{12} ≈ \boxed{28.88 \text{ hours}} \approx 29 \text{ hours}t1/2​=120.693×500​=12346.5​≈28.88 hours​≈29 hours

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. 29 hours

Let me know if you'd like a table of formulas for PK calculations (e.g., loading dose, maintenance dose, etc.).

375

How does Cromolyn reduce bronchial reactivity?

A. Relaxing smooth muscle cells

B. Inhibiting mediated mast cell degranulation.

C. Inhibiting eosinophil chemotactic factor

D. Direct bronchodilation

Here is the evaluation of each option regarding cromolyn’s mechanism in reducing bronchial reactivity, based strictly on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, 2024 edition:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Quote

A. Relaxing smooth muscle cells

❌ Wrong

“Cromolyn has no direct effect on airway smooth muscle, and it does not cause bronchodilation.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Inhibiting mediated mast cell degranulation

✅ Correct

“Cromolyn inhibits antigen- and exercise-induced asthma by preventing mast cell degranulation.” This stabilizes mast cells and prevents the release of histamine and other mediators. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. Inhibiting eosinophil chemotactic factor

❌ Wrong

Cromolyn does not specifically inhibit eosinophil chemotactic factors, although its mast cell-stabilizing effects may have some downstream impact. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Direct bronchodilation

❌ Wrong

“Cromolyn is not a bronchodilator and is not useful in acute asthma attacks.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

✅ Correct answer: B. Inhibiting mediated mast cell degranulation

Let me know if you'd like a comparison of asthma medications by mechanism and clinical use.

376

Which of the following drugs can cause hypoprothrombinemia?

A. Cefuroxime

B. Cefaclor

C. Cefotetan

D. Cefazolin

Here is the evaluation of each option regarding hypoprothrombinemia caused by cephalosporins, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Justification from Katzung

A. Cefuroxime

❌ Wrong

Cefuroxime is a second-generation cephalosporin but not associated with hypoprothrombinemia.

B. Cefaclor

❌ Wrong

Cefaclor is also a second-generation cephalosporin and does not impair vitamin K metabolism.

C. Cefotetan

✅ Correct

“Cefotetan contains an N-methylthiotetrazole (MTT) side chain that can interfere with vitamin K–dependent clotting factor synthesis, leading to hypoprothrombinemia and bleeding.” 【Katzung Ch. 43†】

D. Cefazolin

❌ Wrong

Cefazolin is a first-generation cephalosporin and not associated with hypoprothrombinemia. It lacks the MTT side chain.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. Cefotetan

Let me know if you'd like a table of cephalosporins with special toxicities or unique side chains.

377

Regarding cannabinoids, which of the following statements is correct?

A. They produce tachycardia

B. They constrict the pupils

C. They have an antipsychotic action

D. They act on a number of non-specific receptors

Here is the evaluation of each statement regarding cannabinoids, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (16th ed., 2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. They produce tachycardia

✅ Correct

“Cannabinoids such as THC can produce tachycardia as a common cardiovascular effect.” This is well-documented in both acute and chronic use1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

B. They constrict the pupils

❌ Wrong

Cannabinoids typically cause conjunctival injection (red eyes) but do not cause miosis (pupil constriction) — in fact, pupillary changes are minimal or inconsistent1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. They have an antipsychotic action

❌ Wrong

“Cannabis may cause psychotic symptoms, including paranoia and hallucinations, particularly in high doses or predisposed individuals.” Some synthetic cannabinoids are being studied, but THC is not antipsychotic1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

D. They act on a number of non-specific receptors

❌ Wrong

“Cannabinoids exert their effects mainly via specific cannabinoid receptors (CB1 and CB2).” These are well-defined G protein–coupled receptors, not non-specific1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

 

✅ Answer: A. They produce tachycardia

This is the correct statement — tachycardia is a consistent and well-known physiological effect of cannabinoids like THC.

378

Which of the following drugs doesnotprolong the refractory period of normal cardiac cells?

A. Amiodarone

B. Sotalol

C. Lignocaine

D. Quinidine

Here is the evaluation of which drug does not prolong the refractory period of normal cardiac cells, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. Amiodarone

❌ Wrong

Amiodarone markedly prolongs the action potential duration and QT interval by blocking I<sub>Kr</sub>, extending the refractory period301_Katzun Pharm Split_….

B. Sotalol

❌ Wrong

Sotalol is a class III agent that prolongs action potential duration and refractory period, with a strong effect on QT prolongation301_Katzun Pharm Split_….

C. Lignocaine (Lidocaine)

✅ Correct

Lidocaine does not prolong the refractory period of normal cells; in fact, it slightly shortens it in normal tissue. It has selective effects in ischemic tissue301_Katzun Pharm Split_….

D. Quinidine

❌ Wrong

Quinidine prolongs the refractory period by blocking sodium and potassium channels, leading to QT prolongation301_Katzun Pharm Split_….

 

✅ Correct answer: C. Lignocaine

Let me know if you’d like a full summary table of Class I–IV antiarrhythmic effects!

379

An elderly patient presents to your ED with mild heart failure. Vital assessment BP 110/80, pulse 85/min sinus rhythm. She requires an adjustment of her medications. She is on an ACE inhibitor and a diuretic. What drug would be an appropriate addition to her anti failure regime?

A. Digoxin

B. Hydralazine

C. Bisoprolol

D. Verapamil

Here is the evaluation of options for medication adjustment in an elderly patient with mild heart failure, already on an ACE inhibitor and diuretic:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. Digoxin

❌ Wrong

Digoxin is not first-line in sinus rhythm and is only used if diuretics and ACE inhibitors fail or if the patient has atrial fibrillation301_Katzun Pharm Split_….

B. Hydralazine

❌ Wrong

Hydralazine is considered when fatigue due to low output is predominant, or in combination with nitrates, particularly in Black patients or those unable to take ACE inhibitors301_Katzun Pharm Split_….

C. Bisoprolol

✅ Correct

Beta blockers like bisoprolol are recommended in all stable patients with mild to moderate heart failure as they improve survival and reduce hospitalizations.

D. Verapamil

❌ Wrong

Verapamil is contraindicated in heart failure due to negative inotropic effects, which can worsen the condition.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. Bisoprolol

→ Bisoprolol is one of the three beta blockers proven to reduce mortality in heart failure (along with carvedilol and metoprolol succinate), and is appropriate in this stable patient with mild disease.

380

A patient fractures his wrist. He receives a Bier’s block to reduce the fracture. Soon after drug administration he becomes cyanosed and his blood has a chocolate colour. Which local anaesthetic drug is responsible?

A. Lignociane

B. Bupivacaine

C. Ropivacaine

D. Prilocaine

Here is the evaluation of each local anesthetic regarding the adverse effect of methemoglobinemia (chocolate-colored blood, cyanosis), based strictly on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, 2024 edition:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Quote

A. Lignocaine (Lidocaine)

❌ Wrong

Lidocaine is commonly used in regional anesthesia and does not typically cause methemoglobinemia. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Bupivacaine

❌ Wrong

Bupivacaine is cardiotoxic in high doses, but not associated with methemoglobinemia. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. Ropivacaine

❌ Wrong

Ropivacaine is similar to bupivacaine but with less cardiotoxicity, and not linked to methemoglobinemia. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Prilocaine

✅ Correct

“Prilocaine can cause methemoglobinemia, especially when used in large doses (e.g., during Bier’s block), due to its o-toluidine metabolite.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

✅ Correct answer: D. Prilocaine

Let me know if you'd like a side-effect comparison chart for local anesthetics.

381

Regarding amphotericin B, which of the following statements is correct?

A. It can be given orally to treat systemic illness

B. Its dose needs to be reduced in mild renal impairment

C. It can cause fever, headache and confusion

D. Liver toxicity is the most significant toxic side effect

Here is the evaluation of each option regarding amphotericin B, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Justification from Katzung

A. It can be given orally to treat systemic illness

❌ Wrong

“Amphotericin B is not absorbed orally and must be given intravenously for systemic infections.” Oral forms are only used for luminal infections (e.g., candidiasis of the GI tract). 【Katzung Ch. 48†】

B. Its dose needs to be reduced in mild renal impairment

❌ Wrong

While nephrotoxicity is a major concern, dose adjustment is not routinely recommended for mild renal impairment. Close monitoring is preferred. 【Katzung Ch. 48†】

C. It can cause fever, headache and confusion

✅ Correct

Amphotericin B commonly causes infusion-related reactions, including fever, chills, headache, and sometimes confusion during administration. These are distinct from its dose-limiting nephrotoxicity. 【Katzung Ch. 48†】

D. Liver toxicity is the most significant toxic side effect

❌ Wrong

The most significant toxicity is nephrotoxicity, not liver toxicity. “Renal damage is the most significant toxic reaction associated with amphotericin B.” 【Katzung Ch. 48†】

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. It can cause fever, headache and confusion

Let me know if you'd like a toxicity comparison between amphotericin B and azoles.

382

Regarding heparin, which of the following statements is correct?

A. LMW fractions have more effect on thrombin than HMW fractions

B. Protamine is a competitive antagonist of heparin

C. It may cause alopecia

D. It inhibits antithrombin III

Here is the evaluation of each statement regarding heparin, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (16th ed., 2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. LMW fractions have more effect on thrombin than HMW fractions

❌ Wrong

“Low molecular weight (LMW) heparins are less effective at inhibiting thrombin (factor IIa) because they are too short to bridge antithrombin to thrombin. They are more selective for factor Xa.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Protamine is a competitive antagonist of heparin

❌ Wrong

“Protamine sulfate is a chemical antagonist, not a competitive receptor antagonist. It is a strongly basic protein that binds ionically to heparin to form a stable, inactive complex.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. It may cause alopecia

✅ Correct

“Heparin therapy has been associated with rare adverse effects, including reversible alopecia.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. It inhibits antithrombin III

❌ Wrong

“Heparin activates antithrombin III, enhancing its ability to inhibit thrombin and factor Xa.” It does not inhibit ATIII — it enhances its function1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

 

✅ Answer: C. It may cause alopecia

Reversible alopecia is a recognized, though uncommon, adverse effect of heparin therapy, making Option C the correct answer.

383

A high degree of tolerance can be expected to all these effects of morphine EXCEPT?

A. Analgesia

B. Cough supression

C. Miosis

D. Nausea

Here is the evaluation of which morphine effect does not develop high tolerance, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. Analgesia

❌ Wrong

Tolerance to analgesia is high, as shown in Table 31-3 of Katzung801_Katzun Pharm Split_….

B. Cough suppression

❌ Wrong

Although not explicitly listed in the table, cough suppression shares CNS mechanisms with analgesia and sedation, which are subject to moderate to high tolerance.

C. Miosis

✅ Correct

Tolerance to miosis is minimal or none. It is consistently listed among effects that do not develop tolerance, even after prolonged use801_Katzun Pharm Split_….

D. Nausea

❌ Wrong

Nausea is not listed directly, but opioid-induced nausea stems from CNS actions (CTZ), which can become partially tolerant over time, but not reliably absent, especially in early dosing.

 

✅ Correct answer: C. Miosis

“Table 31–3: Degrees of tolerance that may develop to some of the effects of the opioids... Minimal or None: Miosis, Constipation, Convulsions”801_Katzun Pharm Split_….

384

Regarding gentamicin, which of the following statements is correct?

A. It is not nephrotoxic

B. It has a large theraputic index

C. It decreases the effect of neuromuscular junction blocking drugs

D. It enters cells by an oxygen dependent influx

Here’s the evaluation of the statements about gentamicin, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. It is not nephrotoxic

❌ Wrong

“All aminoglycosides are ototoxic and nephrotoxic.… Gentamicin is among the most nephrotoxic.”1201_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. It has a large therapeutic index

❌ Wrong

Gentamicin has a narrow therapeutic window, requiring close monitoring of peak and trough levels to avoid toxicity1201_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. It decreases the effect of neuromuscular junction blocking drugs

❌ Wrong

Aminoglycosides, including gentamicin, potentiate neuromuscular blockade, and may cause paralysis, especially in those with myasthenia gravis or when used with other neuromuscular blockers.

D. It enters cells by an oxygen-dependent influx

✅ Correct

“Aminoglycosides enter bacteria by an oxygen-dependent active transport mechanism,” which is why they are ineffective against anaerobes1201_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. It enters cells by an oxygen-dependent influx

This is a unique property of aminoglycosides and explains both their selective gram-negative aerobic activity and ineffectiveness against anaerobic organisms.

385

Insulin causes which of the following effects?

A. Inhibits glycogenolysis in the liver

B. Lipoprotein lipase is inhibited by insulin to hydrolyze triglycerides from lipoproteins

C. Decreases triglyceride synthesis and very-low density lipoprotein formation

D. Decreases ribosomal protein synthesis in muscle

Here is the evaluation of each statement regarding insulin’s effects, based strictly on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, 2024 edition:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Quote

A. Inhibits glycogenolysis in the liver

✅ Correct

“Insulin inhibits glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis in the liver while promoting glycogen synthesis.” This is one of insulin’s key metabolic actions. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Lipoprotein lipase is inhibited by insulin to hydrolyze triglycerides from lipoproteins

❌ Wrong

Insulin stimulates, not inhibits, lipoprotein lipase, which hydrolyzes triglycerides from circulating lipoproteins into free fatty acids. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. Decreases triglyceride synthesis and very-low density lipoprotein (VLDL) formation

❌ Wrong

Insulin increases triglyceride synthesis and promotes VLDL formation in the liver. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Decreases ribosomal protein synthesis in muscle

❌ Wrong

Insulin stimulates amino acid uptake and increases protein synthesis via ribosomes in muscle. It is an anabolic hormone. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

✅ Correct answer: A. Inhibits glycogenolysis in the liver

Let me know if you'd like a summary chart of insulin’s metabolic effects across tissues.

386

Which of the following eye drops reduce aqueous humour secretion?

A. Latanoprost

B. Epinephrine

C. Pilocarpine

D. Timolol

Here is the evaluation of each option regarding eye drops that reduce aqueous humour secretion, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Justification from Katzung

A. Latanoprost

❌ Wrong

Latanoprost is a prostaglandin F₂α analog that works by increasing uveoscleral outflow, not by reducing aqueous secretion. 【Katzung Ch. 10†】

B. Epinephrine

❌ Wrong

Epinephrine increases outflow via the trabecular meshwork (α receptors), but also has β effects that may increase secretion — not used primarily to reduce aqueous humour formation.

C. Pilocarpine

❌ Wrong

Pilocarpine is a muscarinic agonist that increases outflow by contracting the ciliary muscle, not by decreasing production of aqueous humour. 【Katzung Ch. 10†】

D. Timolol

✅ Correct

Timolol is a non-selective β-blocker that acts on ciliary epithelium to reduce aqueous humour production, and is widely used in glaucoma. “β-blockers reduce aqueous secretion from the ciliary epithelium.” 【Katzung Ch. 10†】

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. Timolol

Let me know if you'd like a full table of antiglaucoma drugs by mechanism and class.

387

Neonates have which of the following?

A. An increased total body water

B. Increased protein binding

C. An increased clearance of drugs by glomerular filtration

D. Increased hepatic enzymes

Here is the evaluation of each option regarding neonatal physiology and drug pharmacokinetics, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (16th ed., 2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. An increased total body water

✅ Correct

“Neonates have a higher total body water content (~70–75%) compared to adults (~50–60%).” This affects drug distribution, especially for hydrophilic drugs1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

B. Increased protein binding

❌ Wrong

“Neonates have reduced plasma protein concentrations and lower affinity for drug binding, resulting in decreased protein binding.” This increases free (active) drug levels1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. An increased clearance of drugs by glomerular filtration

❌ Wrong

“Glomerular filtration rate (GFR), tubular secretion, and reabsorption are all reduced in neonates, leading to slower renal drug clearance.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Increased hepatic enzymes

❌ Wrong

“Many hepatic drug-metabolizing enzymes are immature in neonates, resulting in reduced metabolic capacity.” This affects both Phase I and Phase II metabolism1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

 

✅ Answer: A. An increased total body water

Neonates have a higher percentage of total body water, which significantly influences the volume of distribution for water-soluble drugs.

388

Which of the following is not a DIRECT ACTING anticoagulant?

A. Heparin

B. Dabigatran

C. Rivaroxaban

D. Argatroban

Here is the evaluation of which anticoagulant is not a direct-acting agent, based strictly on Katzung's Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. Heparin

✅ Correct

Heparin is indirect-acting, as it exerts its anticoagulant effect by activating antithrombin III, which then inactivates thrombin and factor Xa. It does not directly inhibit clotting enzymes901_Katzun Pharm Split_….

B. Dabigatran

❌ Wrong

Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor (DOAC), acting directly on thrombin (factor IIa)901_Katzun Pharm Split_….

C. Rivaroxaban

❌ Wrong

Rivaroxaban is a direct factor Xa inhibitor, another direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC)901_Katzun Pharm Split_….

D. Argatroban

❌ Wrong

Argatroban is an intravenous direct thrombin inhibitor, used especially in patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT)901_Katzun Pharm Split_….

 

✅ Correct answer: A. Heparin

It is the only indirect anticoagulant among the listed options.

389

A male being treated for gout presents with diarrhoea and vomiting. His blood tests demonstrate acute renal failure. Which medication is likely to account for his symptoms?

A. Colchicine

B. Probenecid

C. Allopurinol

D. Prednisolone

Here is the evaluation of the drugs listed in relation to the patient’s symptoms (diarrhea, vomiting, acute renal failure), based strictly on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. Colchicine

✅ Correct

“Colchicine often causes diarrhea and may occasionally cause nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain… acute renal failure… have been observed.”1001_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Probenecid

❌ Wrong

Associated with rash, GI irritation, and rarely aplastic anemia, but not typically acute renal failure or severe GI upset1001_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. Allopurinol

❌ Wrong

Can cause rash, interstitial nephritis, and GI upset, but not commonly both diarrhea/vomiting and acute renal failure together in the same acute context1001_Katzun Pharm Split….

D. Prednisolone

❌ Wrong

Not associated with this triad of GI and renal symptoms acutely.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. Colchicine

“Adverse Effects: colchicine often causes diarrhea and may occasionally cause nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain… acute renal failure… has also been observed.”

— Katzung 20241001_Katzun Pharm Split….

This pattern aligns perfectly with the clinical scenario described.

390

A patient with ESRF (end stage renal failure) presents with constipation. You are worried about fluid shifts and electrolyte disturbances. Which is the best muscle relaxant to use to keep him paralysed?

A. Atracurium

B. Pancuronium

C. Rocuronium

D. Vecuronium

Here is the evaluation of each neuromuscular blocker in the context of end-stage renal failure (ESRF), based strictly on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, 2024 edition:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Quote

A. Atracurium

✅ Correct

“Atracurium is inactivated by Hofmann elimination, a process that is independent of renal or hepatic function.” It is ideal for patients with renal failure, as no accumulation occurs. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Pancuronium

❌ Wrong

“Pancuronium is eliminated primarily by the kidney.” In ESRF, it can accumulate and prolong paralysis. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. Rocuronium

❌ Wrong

Rocuronium is eliminated by both liver and kidney, and clearance is impaired in renal failure, leading to prolonged effect. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Vecuronium

❌ Wrong

Vecuronium undergoes hepatic metabolism, but partial renal excretion, making it less suitable in ESRF. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

✅ Correct answer: A. Atracurium

Let me know if you'd like a comparison chart of neuromuscular blockers by metabolism and renal safety.

391

A patient requires treatment for benign prostatic hyperplasia. Which of the following antiandrogens is a 5 alpha reductase inhibitor?

A. Finansteride

B. Spironolactone

C. Flutamide

D. Cyproterone acetate

Here is the evaluation of each option regarding antiandrogens used in benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and their mechanism, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Justification from Katzung

A. Finasteride

✅ Correct

“Finasteride inhibits 5α-reductase, the enzyme that converts testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), which is involved in prostatic growth. It is used to treat BPH and male pattern baldness.” 【Katzung Ch. 40†】

B. Spironolactone

❌ Wrong

Spironolactone is a mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist that also blocks androgen receptors, but it does not inhibit 5α-reductase. Used in hirsutism and heart failure.

C. Flutamide

❌ Wrong

Flutamide is a nonsteroidal androgen receptor antagonist, not a 5α-reductase inhibitor. It blocks the action of DHT but does not prevent its formation.

D. Cyproterone acetate

❌ Wrong

Cyproterone acetate is a steroidal antiandrogen and progestin, but it also acts by blocking androgen receptors, not by inhibiting 5α-reductase.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. Finasteride

Let me know if you'd like a comparison of antiandrogens used in BPH, prostate cancer, and hirsutism.

392

Which of the following local anaesthetics shortens the action potential duration?

A. Lignocaine

B. Bupivacaine

C. Prilocaine

D. Ropivacaine

Here is the evaluation of each local anesthetic based on its effect on action potential duration, using Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (16th ed., 2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. Lignocaine (Lidocaine)

✅ Correct

“Lidocaine, a Class IB antiarrhythmic, preferentially binds to inactivated Na⁺ channels and shortens the action potential duration in depolarized tissue.” This effect is distinctive among local anesthetics and antiarrhythmics1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

B. Bupivacaine

❌ Wrong

“Bupivacaine is more cardiotoxic and has prolonged action potential duration due to strong and sustained Na⁺ channel binding.” It does not shorten APD1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. Prilocaine

❌ Wrong

“Prilocaine is less potent and less toxic but has no specific effect on shortening action potential duration like lidocaine.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Ropivacaine

❌ Wrong

“Ropivacaine is similar to bupivacaine but less cardiotoxic; it does not shorten the action potential duration.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

 

✅ Answer: A. Lignocaine (Lidocaine)

Lidocaine is the only listed local anesthetic that shortens the action potential duration, especially in ischemic or depolarized cardiac tissue — a property also utilized in its antiarrhythmic use (Class IB).

393

A young man is injected with an iv drug. He shows a resultant tachycardia, midriasis, normal blood pressure and reduced sweating. Which of the following drugs is most likely to have caused this?

A. Nicotinic antagonist

B. Adrenergic agonist

C. Muscarinic antagonist

D. Cholinomimitic

The clinical signs described — tachycardia, mydriasis, normal BP, and reduced sweating — are most consistent with muscarinic antagonism. Here's a breakdown:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. Nicotinic antagonist

❌ Wrong

Nicotinic blockade (e.g. ganglionic blockers) would cause hypotension, not normal BP. Also, CNS agitation and mydriasis are not prominent features.

B. Adrenergic agonist

❌ Wrong

Would cause tachycardia and mydriasis, but usually increase BP and not reduce sweating.

C. Muscarinic antagonist

✅ Correct

Causes mydriasis, tachycardia, dry skin (↓ sweating), agitation, and normal or elevated temp/BP — this matches atropine toxicity. As Katzung notes: "Poisoned individuals manifest dry mouth, mydriasis, tachycardia, hot and flushed skin, agitation, and delirium..."201_Katzun Pharm Split_….

D. Cholinomimetic

❌ Wrong

Would cause bradycardia, miosis, diaphoresis, and increased secretions, the opposite of the symptoms described.

 

✅ Correct answer: C. Muscarinic antagonist (e.g. atropine).

394

Regarding ketamine, which of the following statements is correct?

A. It is a bronchoconstrictor

B. It can cause agitation and an emergence phenomina in children

C. It increases respiratory rate initially

D. It has no cardiovascular effects

Here is the evaluation of each statement regarding ketamine, based strictly on Katzung's Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. It is a bronchoconstrictor

❌ Wrong

“Ketamine relaxes bronchial smooth muscle and may be helpful in patients with reactive airways and in the management of patients experiencing bronchoconstriction.” — i.e., it is a bronchodilator, not a bronchoconstrictor701_Katzun Pharm Split_….

B. It can cause agitation and an emergence phenomenon in children

✅ Correct

“Despite the unpleasant psychomimetic effects… especially in children, the risk for laryngospasm due to increased salivation must be considered” — emergence reactions, such as agitation and hallucinations, are known side effects, especially in pediatric use701_Katzun Pharm Split_….

C. It increases respiratory rate initially

❌ Wrong

Ketamine does not increase respiratory rate; it preserves respiratory drive but may cause transient hypoventilation or apnea with rapid IV administration701_Katzun Pharm Split_….

D. It has no cardiovascular effects

❌ Wrong

“Ketamine can produce transient but significant increases in systemic blood pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output...” — so it definitely has cardiovascular effects701_Katzun Pharm Split_….

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. It can cause agitation and an emergence phenomenon in children

Let me know if you want a summary table on ketamine's systemic effects (CNS, cardiovascular, respiratory).

395

Which dopaminergic systems are important for the understanding of schizophrenia

A. Mesolimbic-mesocortical pathway

B. Medullary-periventricular pathway

C. Nigrostriatal pathway

D. Tuberoinfundibular pathway

Here is the evaluation of each dopaminergic pathway in relation to schizophrenia, based strictly on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, 2024 edition:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Quote

A. Mesolimbic–mesocortical pathway

✅ Correct

“The mesolimbic and mesocortical pathways are thought to be most closely related to behavior and psychosis, and are implicated in the pathophysiology of schizophrenia.” Increased dopamine activity in the mesolimbic system is associated with positive symptoms, while decreased activity in the mesocortical pathway is linked to negative symptoms. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Medullary–periventricular pathway

❌ Wrong

This pathway is involved in eating behavior, not in psychosis or schizophrenia. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. Nigrostriatal pathway

❌ Wrong

The nigrostriatal system is primarily involved in movement control; it's affected in Parkinson's disease and causes extrapyramidal side effects when blocked by antipsychotics, but not directly involved in schizophrenia pathogenesis. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Tuberoinfundibular pathway

❌ Wrong

This pathway regulates prolactin secretion; antipsychotic blockade here causes hyperprolactinemia, but it is not implicated in schizophrenia symptoms. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

✅ Correct answer: A. Mesolimbic–mesocortical pathway

Let me know if you'd like a diagram or summary of dopaminergic pathways and their clinical relevance.

396

What is the equivalent dose of dexamethasone and prednisolone compared to 200mg hydrocortisone?

A. 1mg, 10mg

B. 8mg, 50mg

C. 2mg, 20mg

D. 2mg, 25mg

To determine the equivalent doses of dexamethasone and prednisolone compared to 200 mg of hydrocortisone, we use the glucocorticoid potency equivalence table provided in Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

📊 Relative Potencies (Glucocorticoid activity):

Drug

Approximate Equivalent Dose

Relative Potency

Hydrocortisone

20 mg

1

Prednisolone

5 mg

4

Dexamethasone

0.75 mg

~25–30

 

🔍 Calculations:

  • 200 mg hydrocortisone ÷ 20 mg = 10× standard dose
  • Equivalent prednisolone dose: 10 × 5 mg = 50 mg
  • Equivalent dexamethasone dose: 10 × 0.75 mg = 7.5 mg (rounded to 8 mg)

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. 8 mg, 50 mg

Let me know if you'd like a corticosteroid equivalency table for clinical use.

397

Regarding propranolol, which of  the following statements is correct?

A. It has Na+ blocking activity

B. It is minimally lipid soluble

C. It is beta 1 selective

D. It has intrinsic sympathomimetic activity

Here is the evaluation of each statement regarding propranolol, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (16th ed., 2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. It has Na⁺ blocking activity

✅ Correct

“Propranolol, at high concentrations, blocks sodium channels and exerts membrane-stabilizing (quinidine-like) effects.” This is an important property, especially at toxic doses1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

B. It is minimally lipid soluble

❌ Wrong

“Propranolol is highly lipid-soluble, which allows it to readily cross the blood-brain barrier and cause CNS effects (e.g., vivid dreams, sedation).”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. It is beta-1 selective

❌ Wrong

“Propranolol is a nonselective β-blocker, meaning it blocks both β1 and β2 receptors.” It is not cardioselective1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

D. It has intrinsic sympathomimetic activity (ISA)

❌ Wrong

“Propranolol has no intrinsic sympathomimetic activity (ISA).” Some β-blockers like pindolol do, but not propranolol1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

 

✅ Answer: A. It has Na⁺ blocking activity

Propranolol exhibits membrane-stabilizing effects by blocking sodium channels, especially at high doses, making this the correct answer.

398

What is meant by the term therapeutic index?

A. The minimum dose at which a drug has a clinically relevant effect

B. The ratio of the median effective dose to the median toxic dose

C. The ratio of the median toxic dose to the median effective dose

D. The difference between the minimum toxic dose and minimum therapeutic dose

Here is the evaluation of the options regarding the therapeutic index, based strictly on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. The minimum dose at which a drug has a clinically relevant effect

❌ Wrong

This describes the minimum effective dose, not the therapeutic index.

B. The ratio of the median effective dose to the median toxic dose

❌ Wrong

This reverses the correct relationship.

C. The ratio of the median toxic dose to the median effective dose

✅ Correct

“The therapeutic index is usually defined as the ratio of the TD₅₀ to the ED₅₀ for some therapeutically relevant effect.”1_Katzun Pharm Split_To….

D. The difference between the minimum toxic dose and minimum therapeutic dose

❌ Wrong

This describes the therapeutic window, not the therapeutic index1_Katzun Pharm Split_To….

 

✅ Correct answer: C. The ratio of the median toxic dose to the median effective dose.

399

Which of the following drug drug clases interact dangerously with Monoamine Oxidase Inhibitors (MAOI)

A. Selective Serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI)

B. Tetracyclic antidepressants

C. Tricyclic antidepressants

D. 5 HT2 antagonists

Here is the evaluation of the drug classes for dangerous interactions with MAOIs, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRI)

✅ Correct

“The first of these is the pharmacodynamic interaction of MAOIs with serotonergic agents including SSRIs... These combinations... may result in a life-threatening serotonin syndrome.”801_Katzun Pharm Split_…

B. Tetracyclic antidepressants

❌ Wrong

Not specifically listed among the major interacting serotonergic classes in Katzung. Risk may exist but less established.

C. Tricyclic antidepressants

✅ Correct

Katzung includes TCAs as serotonergic agents that can cause serotonin syndrome when combined with MAOIs801_Katzun Pharm Split_….

D. 5-HT₂ antagonists

❌ Wrong

These are not serotonergic stimulators, and not known to cause serotonin syndrome when used with MAOIs.

 

 

✅ Correct Answers: A. SSRIs and C. TCAs

Let me know if you’d like a visual of drug classes that cause serotonin syndrome with MAOIs.

400

Which of the following antibiotics does not exert its action by inhibiting cell wall synthesis?

A. Vancomycin

B. Imipenem

C. Erythromycin

D. Ceftriaxone

Here is the evaluation of each antibiotic regarding inhibition of bacterial cell wall synthesis, based strictly on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, 2024 edition:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Quote

A. Vancomycin

❌ Wrong

“Vancomycin inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of peptidoglycan precursors.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Imipenem

❌ Wrong

“Imipenem is a β-lactam antibiotic (a carbapenem) that inhibits cell wall synthesis by binding penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs).” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. Erythromycin

✅ Correct

“Erythromycin is a macrolide antibiotic that inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit.” It does not affect cell wall synthesis. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Ceftriaxone

❌ Wrong

“Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin, a β-lactam drug that inhibits cell wall synthesis by interfering with cross-linking of peptidoglycan.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

✅ Correct answer: C. Erythromycin

Let me know if you'd like a table grouping antibiotics by their mechanism of action.

401

A pregnant woman presents with involuntary neck stiffness following an antiemetic. Which drug is most likely to cause this?

A. Ondansetron

B. Dexamethasone

C. Metoclopramide

D. Domperidone

Here is the evaluation of each option regarding extrapyramidal side effects (e.g., neck stiffness/dystonia) caused by antiemetics in pregnancy, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Justification from Katzung

A. Ondansetron

❌ Wrong

Ondansetron is a 5-HT₃ antagonist and does not block dopamine receptors. It is not associated with extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS). 【Katzung Ch. 62†】

B. Dexamethasone

❌ Wrong

Dexamethasone is a glucocorticoid, occasionally used as an antiemetic in chemotherapy, but not associated with EPS.

C. Metoclopramide

✅ Correct

“Metoclopramide is a dopamine D2 receptor antagonist in the chemoreceptor trigger zone,” and can cause extrapyramidal side effects, including acute dystonic reactions, especially in young adults and children. 【Katzung Ch. 62†】

D. Domperidone

❌ Wrong

Domperidone is a D2 antagonist but does not cross the blood-brain barrier well, so it has a much lower risk of EPS compared to metoclopramide. 【Katzung Ch. 62†】

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. Metoclopramide

Let me know if you’d like a table comparing antiemetics by mechanism and side effect profile.

402

A patient on phenytoin is found to have a low blood phenytoin level. Of the following drugs, which is LEAST likely to cause this?

A. Carbemazepime

B. Hypoalbuminemia

C. Non-compliance

D. Disulfiram

Here is the evaluation of each option regarding its likelihood of causing a low blood phenytoin level, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (16th ed., 2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. Carbamazepine

❌ Wrong

“Carbamazepine is a known CYP450 enzyme inducer and increases the metabolism of phenytoin, thereby lowering its blood concentration.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Hypoalbuminemia

❌ Wrong

“Phenytoin is highly protein-bound (~90%). In hypoalbuminemia, total phenytoin level appears low, but free (active) drug level may be normal or elevated.” So it can show low measured levels but not necessarily reduced effect1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. Non-compliance

❌ Wrong

Obviously, if the patient is not taking the drug as prescribed, blood levels will be low. This is a common and likely cause.

D. Disulfiram

✅ Correct

“Disulfiram is a CYP2C9 inhibitor, which reduces phenytoin metabolism, leading to increased phenytoin levels, not decreased.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

 

✅ Answer: D. Disulfiram

Disulfiram is the least likely to cause low phenytoin levels, as it inhibits phenytoin metabolism, potentially increasing its blood concentration.

403

Which NSAID is reported to have the lowest gastro-intestinal upset

A. Celecoxib

B. Diclofenac

C. Naproxen

D. Ibuprofen

Here’s the evaluation of NSAIDs based on their gastrointestinal (GI) side effect profile, from Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Drug

GI Side Effect Risk

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. Celecoxib

Lowest

✅ Correct

Celecoxib is a selective COX-2 inhibitor, and “has a significantly lower incidence of GI ulceration and bleeding compared with nonselective NSAIDs”1001_Katzun Pharm Split….

B. Diclofenac

Moderate to high

❌ Wrong

Nonselective COX inhibitor; carries GI risk typical of traditional NSAIDs.

C. Naproxen

Higher than ibuprofen

❌ Wrong

OTC use results in twice the GI bleeding risk compared to ibuprofen1001_Katzun Pharm Split….

D. Ibuprofen

Lower than naproxen

❌ Wrong

Though better than naproxen, not as safe as celecoxib in GI terms1001_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

✅ Correct answer: A. Celecoxib

Its COX-2 selectivity spares the gastric mucosa, making it the preferred NSAID when GI safety is a concern.

404

What is the half life of Lignocaine?

A. 10 minutes

B. 120 minutes

C. 30 minutes

D. 60 minutes

The elimination half-life of lidocaine (lignocaine) is approximately:

1.6 hours (96 minutes)

— as stated in Table 26–2, Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024)701_Katzun Pharm Split_….

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. 120 minutes

This corresponds closely to the standard elimination half-life of 1.5–2 hours for lidocaine under normal conditions.

Let me know if you'd like other PK parameters from that table!

405

A patient with Na = 108 has a seizure and you treat it with 100ml of 3% saline. If this had not been available, what would be an equivalent dose of 8.4% sodium bicarbonate?

A. 40ml

B. 55ml

C. 45ml

D. 50ml

To calculate the equivalent volume of 8.4% sodium bicarbonate that matches the sodium content of 100 mL of 3% saline, we need to compare sodium content per mL in each solution.

 

🧮 Step-by-Step Calculation:

✅ Sodium content in 3% saline:

  • 3% NaCl = 3 g NaCl / 100 mL
  • NaCl = 58.5 g/mol → 3 g NaCl = 3 / 58.5 ≈ 0.05128 mol NaCl
  • Each mole of NaCl = 1 mole of Na⁺ → 0.05128 mol Na⁺
  • Sodium in 100 mL = 0.05128 mol × 1000 = 51.28 mmol Na⁺

 

✅ Sodium content in 8.4% sodium bicarbonate:

  • 8.4% NaHCO₃ = 8.4 g / 100 mL = 0.084 g/mL
  • NaHCO₃ = 84 g/mol → 0.084 g = 1 mmol NaHCO₃ / mL
  • So, 1 mL of 8.4% sodium bicarbonate = 1 mmol Na⁺

 

🔄 Now solve for volume:

To match 51.28 mmol Na⁺, we need:

Volume=51.28 mmol1 mmol/mL=51.28 mL\text{Volume} = \frac{51.28 \text{ mmol}}{1 \text{ mmol/mL}} = 51.28 \text{ mL}Volume=1 mmol/mL51.28 mmol​=51.28 mL

 

✅ Closest answer: D. 50 mL

Let me know if you'd like a quick reference table for sodium content across hypertonic solutions.

406

Why is methadone is used in the treatment of narcotic addiction?

A. It does not produce constipation

B. Tolerance and physical dependence develop more slowly with methadone

C. It is a phenylpiperadine class narcotic agonist

D. It produces a short withdrawl when ceased

Here is the evaluation of each option regarding why methadone is used in the treatment of narcotic (opioid) addiction, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Justification from Katzung

A. It does not produce constipation

❌ Wrong

Methadone, like other opioids, does produce constipation. Katzung states: “Constipation is a common side effect of methadone, as with all μ-opioid agonists.” 【Katzung Ch. 31†】

B. Tolerance and physical dependence develop more slowly with methadone

✅ Correct

“Methadone is used for opioid dependence because it has a long half-life, slow onset, and produces less intense withdrawal, allowing for easier tapering.” Tolerance and dependence develop more slowly, which makes it useful for maintenance therapy. 【Katzung Ch. 31†】

C. It is a phenylpiperidine class narcotic agonist

❌ Wrong

Methadone is not a phenylpiperidine; it is a diphenylheptane derivative. Phenylpiperidines include fentanyl, loperamide, meperidine. 【Katzung Ch. 31†】

D. It produces a short withdrawal when ceased

❌ Wrong

Methadone produces long-lasting withdrawal symptoms due to its long half-life; this is why withdrawal is less intense but more prolonged, and not “short.” 【Katzung Ch. 31†】

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Tolerance and physical dependence develop more slowly with methadone

Let me know if you'd like a comparison chart of methadone vs buprenorphine for opioid substitution therapy.

407

Regarding zidovudine (AZT), which of the following statements is correct?

A. It has a short half life

B. It has a similar mechanism of action to amantadine

C. It blocks thymidine kinase

D. It is not used to treat retroviruses

Here is the evaluation of each statement regarding zidovudine (AZT), based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (16th ed., 2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. It has a short half-life

✅ Correct

“Zidovudine has a plasma half-life of approximately 1 hour, but the intracellular half-life of its active triphosphate form is longer (3–4 hours).” So while short, it still supports dosing every 8 hours1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

B. It has a similar mechanism of action to amantadine

❌ Wrong

“Amantadine blocks viral uncoating (influenza A), whereas AZT is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI), which inhibits reverse transcription in retroviruses.” Very different mechanisms1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. It blocks thymidine kinase

❌ Wrong

“Zidovudine requires phosphorylation by host cellular kinases, not viral thymidine kinase. It is not a thymidine kinase inhibitor.” This is more relevant to drugs like acyclovir1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

D. It is not used to treat retroviruses

❌ Wrong

“Zidovudine is one of the earliest drugs used to treat retroviruses, particularly HIV, which is a retrovirus.” This is its primary indication1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

 

✅ Answer: A. It has a short half-life

Zidovudine (AZT) has a short plasma half-life (~1 hour), though its intracellular active form lasts longer. It is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor used in retroviral therapy (e.g., HIV).

408

Which drug has both a greater anti-inflammatory and salt-retaining effecting than hydrocortisone?

A. Fludrocortisone

B. Betamethasone

C. Prednisolone

D. Dexmaethasone

Here is the comparison of anti-inflammatory and salt-retaining effects of the listed corticosteroids, based on Table 39–1 from Katzung's Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Drug

Anti-Inflammatory Activity

Salt-Retaining Activity

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. Fludrocortisone

10× hydrocortisone

250× hydrocortisone

✅ Correct

Has both greater anti-inflammatory and markedly greater salt-retaining effects than hydrocortisone (1× baseline)1101_Katzun Pharm Split….

B. Betamethasone

25–40×

0×

❌ Wrong

High anti-inflammatory but no salt-retaining effect.

C. Prednisolone

5×

0.3×

❌ Wrong

Greater anti-inflammatory, but much lower salt-retaining effect.

D. Dexamethasone

30×

0×

❌ Wrong

Potent anti-inflammatory, no salt-retaining activity.

 

✅ Correct answer: A. Fludrocortisone — it exceeds hydrocortisone in both glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid activity1101_Katzun Pharm Split….

409

All of the drugs listed produce similar effects except?

A. Muscarine

B. Methacholine

C. Acetylcholine

D. Hyoscine

Here’s the breakdown of the question based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. Muscarine

✅ Correct

Muscarine is a muscarinic receptor agonist, producing parasympathomimetic effects similar to acetylcholine and methacholine101_Katzun Pharm Split_….

B. Methacholine

✅ Correct

Methacholine is a choline ester with strong muscarinic activity, mimicking acetylcholine’s effects on smooth muscle and glands101_Katzun Pharm Split_….

C. Acetylcholine

✅ Correct

Acetylcholine is the prototype cholinergic agonist, acting at both muscarinic and nicotinic receptors, and directly mimics parasympathetic stimulation101_Katzun Pharm Split_….

D. Hyoscine

❌ Wrong

Hyoscine (scopolamine) is an antimuscarinic agent that blocks muscarinic receptors, producing opposite effects to the others (e.g. mydriasis, dry mouth, tachycardia)101_Katzun Pharm Split_….

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. Hyoscine

All other agents are cholinomimetic (activate muscarinic receptors), while hyoscine is antimuscarinic, and thus produces opposing effects.

410

Regarding pharmacodynamics which of the following statements is true?

A. Potency is maximal drug effect.

B. Efficacy is measured by gram-for-gram effect

C. Potency is dose of maximal effect.

D. Efficacy is the maximal effect of a drug

Here is the evaluation of each statement regarding pharmacodynamics, based strictly on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, 2024 edition:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Quote

A. Potency is maximal drug effect

❌ Wrong

“Potency refers to the dose or concentration of a drug required to produce a given effect, not the maximum effect.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Efficacy is measured by gram-for-gram effect

❌ Wrong

This describes potency, not efficacy. Efficacy is not based on dose size or weight comparison. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. Potency is dose of maximal effect

❌ Wrong

Potency refers to the dose needed to achieve 50% of maximal effect (EC₅₀), not the dose for maximum effect. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Efficacy is the maximal effect of a drug

✅ Correct

“Efficacy is the greatest effect (Emax) a drug can produce, regardless of dose.” It is a measure of the drug’s intrinsic activity, not its dose. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

✅ Correct answer: D. Efficacy is the maximal effect of a drug

Let me know if you'd like a side-by-side chart of potency vs efficacy with example drugs.

411

A woman is taking an antihypertensive medication. Her blood workup reveals an elevated potassium.Which of the following drugs isLEASTlikely to cause this?

A. Frusemide

B. Spironalactone

C. ACE inhibitor

D. Methyldopa

Here is the evaluation of each option regarding antihypertensive drugs and their likelihood of causing hyperkalemia, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Justification from Katzung

A. Frusemide

✅ Correct

Frusemide (furosemide) is a loop diuretic that promotes potassium excretion, often causing hypokalemia, not hyperkalemia. Katzung: “Loop diuretics cause increased potassium excretion.” 【Katzung Ch. 15†】

B. Spironolactone

❌ Wrong

Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and aldosterone antagonist, which can lead to hyperkalemia, especially in patients with renal impairment. 【Katzung Ch. 15†】

C. ACE inhibitor

❌ Wrong

ACE inhibitors decrease aldosterone levels, reducing potassium excretion and thus commonly cause hyperkalemia. 【Katzung Ch. 11†】

D. Methyldopa

❌ Wrong

Methyldopa is a centrally acting α2 agonist and while rarely associated, it can cause hyperkalemia in some cases due to decreased renin and aldosterone. 【Katzung Ch. 11†】

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. Frusemide

(Least likely to cause hyperkalemia)

Let me know if you'd like a table comparing antihypertensives by their electrolyte effects.

412

Regarding nitrates, which of the following statements iscorrect?

A. They increase collateral flow even if there is a fixed constriction

B. They cause an increase in LVED volume

C. They cause significant Methaemaglobinaemia

D. Arteries respond to nitrates at lower doses than veins

Here is the evaluation of each statement regarding nitrates, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (16th ed., 2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. They increase collateral flow even if there is a fixed constriction

✅ Correct

“Nitrates promote redistribution of coronary blood flow, possibly enhancing collateral flow to ischemic areas, even in the presence of a fixed obstruction.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. They cause an increase in LVED volume

❌ Wrong

“Nitrates reduce preload by venodilation, which lowers left ventricular end-diastolic volume (LVEDV) and pressure.” This improves myocardial oxygen demand balance1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. They cause significant methaemoglobinaemia

❌ Wrong

“High doses of nitrates may rarely cause methaemoglobinaemia, but this is not a common or significant clinical concern.” It’s not a typical feature of therapeutic nitrate use1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

D. Arteries respond to nitrates at lower doses than veins

❌ Wrong

“Veins are more sensitive to nitrates than arteries, and respond at lower doses, resulting in decreased preload.” Arterial dilation occurs at higher doses1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

 

✅ Answer: A. They increase collateral flow even if there is a fixed constriction

This is correct — nitrates help redistribute coronary blood flow, potentially improving collateral perfusion to ischemic myocardial tissue, even in the presence of fixed stenosis.

413

Regarding the penicillins, which is INCORRECT?

A. Can be used for enterococcal meningitis.

B. Concentration is most tissues are equal to serum

C. Does not need to be adjusted in renal failure

D. Mostly excreted by tubular secretion

Here is the evaluation of each statement regarding penicillins:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. Can be used for enterococcal meningitis.

✅ Correct

Penicillin is used for meningitis caused by susceptible strains. In combination with aminoglycosides, it can cover enterococci in meningitis1201_Katzun Pharm Split….

B. Concentration in most tissues are equal to serum

✅ Correct

“Penicillin concentrations in most tissues are equal to those in serum”1201_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. Does not need to be adjusted in renal failure

❌ Incorrect

“For penicillins that are cleared by the kidney, the dose must be adjusted according to renal function…”1201_Katzun Pharm Split….

D. Mostly excreted by tubular secretion

✅ Correct

“Tubular secretion accounts for about 90% of renal excretion”1201_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

✅ Correct answer: C. Does not need to be adjusted in renal failure — this is incorrect, and therefore the correct choice for the question.

414

Which of the following cholinoceptor blocking drugs is the least absorbed by the brain?

A. Ipratropium

B. Benztropine

C. Scopolamine

D. Atropine

Here is the evaluation of the cholinoceptor-blocking drugs and their ability to enter the brain (CNS), based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. Ipratropium

✅ Correct

“Ipratropium bromide… can be inhaled in high doses because of its poor absorption into the circulation and poor entry into the CNS.” It is a quaternary ammonium compound, which limits CNS penetration501_Katzun Pharm Split_….

B. Benztropine

❌ Wrong

Benztropine is a tertiary amine and readily enters the CNS, where it is used to treat Parkinsonism and extrapyramidal symptoms.

C. Scopolamine

❌ Wrong

“Scopolamine is rapidly and fully distributed into the CNS, where it has greater effects than most other antimuscarinic drugs”201_Katzun Pharm Split_….

D. Atropine

❌ Wrong

Atropine is also a tertiary amine, widely distributed in the body and achieves significant CNS levels within 30 minutes to 1 hour201_Katzun Pharm Split_….

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. Ipratropium

Its quaternary structure limits CNS absorption, unlike the tertiary amines (atropine, scopolamine, benztropine) which readily cross the blood-brain barrier.

415

Which of the following matches of diuretic and their site of action is correct?

A. Furosemide – Thick ascending limb of Henle

B. Thiazide – Collecting duct

C. Mannitol – Distal convoluted tubule

D. Spironolactone – Proximal convoluted tubule

Here is the evaluation of each diuretic–site of action match, based strictly on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, 2024 edition:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Quote

A. Furosemide – Thick ascending limb of Henle

✅ Correct

“Loop diuretics (e.g., furosemide) act on the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle by inhibiting the Na⁺/K⁺/2Cl⁻ cotransporter.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Thiazide – Collecting duct

❌ Wrong

“Thiazides act at the distal convoluted tubule, inhibiting the Na⁺/Cl⁻ symporter.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. Mannitol – Distal convoluted tubule

❌ Wrong

“Mannitol acts as an osmotic diuretic primarily in the proximal tubule and descending limb of Henle’s loop.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Spironolactone – Proximal convoluted tubule

❌ Wrong

“Spironolactone is an aldosterone antagonist that acts in the collecting duct, not the proximal tubule.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

✅ Correct answer: A. Furosemide – Thick ascending limb of Henle

Let me know if you'd like a nephron diagram with sites of action for different diuretics.

416

Which of the following drugs is a category A drug in pregnancy?

A. Sulfasalazine

B. Metoprolol

C. Dicloxacillin

D. Heparin

Here is the evaluation of each option regarding pregnancy category A drugs, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024) and TGA pregnancy categorization (used in Australia, as the FDA no longer uses A/B/C/D/X system):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Justification from Katzung and TGA classification

A. Sulfasalazine

❌ Wrong

Sulfasalazine is Category C — animal studies have shown some risk, and it may interfere with folate metabolism. Often used in pregnancy with folic acid supplementation.

B. Metoprolol

❌ Wrong

Metoprolol is Category C — beta-blockers may cause fetal bradycardia, hypotension, and hypoglycemia.

C. Dicloxacillin

✅ Correct

Dicloxacillin is a Category A drug — “taken by a large number of pregnant women without any proven increase in frequency of malformations or harmful effects.” It is a penicillinase-resistant penicillin considered safe.

D. Heparin

❌ Wrong

Heparin is Category C (though considered safe in practice) — does not cross the placenta, but classified conservatively due to bleeding risk. 【Katzung Ch. 34†】

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. Dicloxacillin

Let me know if you’d like a table of commonly prescribed pregnancy-safe drugs by category.

417

Sodium Valporate inhibits the metabolism of all of the following drugs EXCEPT?

A. Phenytoin

B. Olanzapine

C. Phenobarbitol

D. Carbamazapine

Here is the evaluation of each drug regarding whether its metabolism is inhibited by sodium valproate, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (16th ed., 2024):

 

🔬 Key Principle:

“Valproic acid is an inhibitor of several hepatic enzymes and can inhibit the metabolism of other antiepileptic drugs, such as phenytoin, phenobarbital, and carbamazepine.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. Phenytoin

❌ Wrong

“Valproate inhibits the metabolism of phenytoin and displaces it from plasma proteins, increasing free drug levels.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Olanzapine

✅ Correct

“Olanzapine is primarily metabolized by CYP1A2 and glucuronidation, and its metabolism is not significantly affected by valproate.” Valproate has no major inhibitory effect on olanzapine clearance1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. Phenobarbitone

❌ Wrong

“Valproic acid can inhibit the metabolism of phenobarbital, leading to increased sedation and toxicity.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Carbamazepine

❌ Wrong

“Valproate can inhibit epoxide hydrolase, an enzyme involved in carbamazepine metabolism, increasing levels of active metabolites.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

 

✅ Answer: B. Olanzapine

Olanzapine is not significantly affected by valproate, making it the correct answer.

The others — phenytoin, phenobarbital, and carbamazepine — all have their metabolism inhibited by sodium valproate.

418

Elderly people havereduced hepaticclearanceof which of the following drugs?

A. Warfarin

B. Salicylate

C. Prazosin

D. Tolbutamide

Based on Katzung's Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024), the hepatic clearance in elderly patients is not significantly reduced for the following:

Drug

Effect of Aging on Hepatic Clearance

Warfarin

❌ No change with age1601_Katzun Pharm Split…

Salicylate

❌ No change with age1601_Katzun Pharm Split…

Prazosin

❌ No change with age1601_Katzun Pharm Split…

Tolbutamide

✅ Decreased clearance with age1601_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

✅ Correct answer: D. Tolbutamide

This is the only drug listed that shows an age-related reduction in hepatic clearance.

419

The type of metabolism which leads to the accumulation of toxic metabolites in a paracetamol overdose is?

A. Methylation

B. Hydroxylation

C. Sulphation

D. Glucuronidation

The type of metabolism that leads to the accumulation of toxic metabolites in paracetamol (acetaminophen) overdose is:

✅ Hydroxylation

 

📘 Katzung's Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024) states:

“Acetaminophen… normally undergoes glucuronidation and sulfation… [but] the alternative P450-dependent (i.e., CYP-mediated hydroxylation) pathway becomes increasingly important when doses are high… leading to accumulation of a reactive toxic metabolite (N-acetylbenzoiminoquinone, or NAPQI)”101_Katzun Pharm Split_….

This CYP450 pathway (specifically CYP2E1) involves hydroxylation reactions, forming NAPQI, which causes hepatotoxicity if glutathione (GSH) is depleted.

 

Final Answer: B. Hydroxylation ✅

Let me know if you'd like a diagram showing this metabolic pathway!

420

Your emergency department wants to buy Sugammadex. You present a CME on the important pharmacodynaics and pharmacokinetic of the drug. Which of the following is true?

A. It is effective in reversing both selective and non selective

B. 4mg/kg is the dose required for immediate reversal of neuromuscular blocker

C. It is safe to use in patients with renal failure

D. Muscle recovery with Sugammadex is faster than neostigmine

Here is the evaluation of each statement regarding sugammadex, based strictly on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, 2024 edition:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Quote

A. It is effective in reversing both selective and non-selective

❌ Wrong

“Sugammadex selectively binds aminosteroid non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers, especially rocuronium and vecuronium. It does not reverse benzylisoquinolinium agents like atracurium.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. 4 mg/kg is the dose required for immediate reversal of neuromuscular blocker

✅ Correct

“For immediate reversal of deep blockade (3 minutes after rocuronium), the recommended dose is 4 mg/kg or more.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. It is safe to use in patients with renal failure

❌ Wrong

“Sugammadex is eliminated via the kidney, and use is not recommended in patients with severe renal impairment due to risk of prolonged exposure.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Muscle recovery with Sugammadex is faster than neostigmine

✅ Correct

“Recovery from rocuronium-induced neuromuscular block is significantly faster with sugammadex compared to neostigmine.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

✅ Correct answers: B and D

However, since the question asks "which of the following is true?" (singular), the **best single correct answer is:

B. 4 mg/kg is the dose required for immediate reversal of neuromuscular blocker

Let me know if you'd like a slide-friendly summary of sugammadex pharmacokinetics and clinical indications.

421

Regarding erythromycin, which of the following statements is correct?

A. It is predominantly renally excreted

B. It is effective against Campylobacter jejuni

C. It is a cell wall inhibitor

D. It is bacteriostatic only

Here is the evaluation of each option regarding erythromycin, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Justification from Katzung

A. It is predominantly renally excreted

❌ Wrong

“Erythromycin is primarily eliminated via the bile and feces.” Only a small fraction is renally excreted, so renal impairment does not require dosage adjustment. 【Katzung Ch. 44†】

B. It is effective against Campylobacter jejuni

✅ Correct

“Erythromycin is the drug of choice for infections caused by Campylobacter jejuni.” It is especially useful in treating bacterial gastroenteritis. 【Katzung Ch. 44†】

C. It is a cell wall inhibitor

❌ Wrong

Erythromycin is a macrolide antibiotic that inhibits protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit, not the cell wall. Cell wall inhibitors include penicillins and cephalosporins. 【Katzung Ch. 44†】

D. It is bacteriostatic only

❌ Wrong

While erythromycin is primarily bacteriostatic, it can be bactericidal at higher concentrations or against very susceptible organisms. 【Katzung Ch. 44†】

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. It is effective against Campylobacter jejuni

Let me know if you'd like a table comparing macrolides by spectrum, mechanism, and clinical use.

422

With the MAOI tranylcypromine, which drug will beleastproblematic?

A. Propofol

B. Phenylephrine

C. Pethidine

D. Ephedrine

Here is the evaluation of each drug in terms of safety when used with tranylcypromine, a monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI), based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (16th ed., 2024):

 

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. Propofol

✅ Correct

“Propofol is a sedative-hypnotic that does not interact with monoamine neurotransmitter systems and is therefore safe to use with MAOIs.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Phenylephrine

❌ Wrong

“Phenylephrine is a direct α1-adrenergic agonist; MAOIs can enhance its pressor effect, increasing the risk of hypertensive crisis.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. Pethidine (Meperidine)

❌ Wrong

“Pethidine is contraindicated with MAOIs due to risk of serotonin syndrome, severe CNS toxicity, and potentially fatal interactions.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Ephedrine

❌ Wrong

“Ephedrine is an indirect sympathomimetic, which can cause dangerous hypertension when combined with MAOIs due to excessive norepinephrine release.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

 

✅ Answer: A. Propofol

Propofol is the least problematic with tranylcypromine (MAOI) because it does not affect monoamine neurotransmitters and does not cause hypertensive or serotonergic crises.

423

Regarding L-dopa, which of the following statements is correct?

A. It has a half life of 5 hours

B. It causes a negative Coombs test.

C. It is a precursor to dopamine

D. 25% of the oral dose reaches the brain

Here is the evaluation of the statements regarding levodopa (L-dopa):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. It has a half-life of 5 hours

❌ Wrong

“The plasma half-life is usually between 1 and 3 hours, although it varies considerably among individuals.”701_Katzun Pharm Split_….

B. It causes a negative Coombs test.

❌ Wrong

This is not mentioned in Katzung; Coombs-negative hemolysis is not a known side effect of levodopa.

C. It is a precursor to dopamine

✅ Correct

“Levodopa, the immediate metabolic precursor of dopamine, does enter the brain... where it is decarboxylated to dopamine”701_Katzun Pharm Split_….

D. 25% of the oral dose reaches the brain

❌ Wrong

Only “1–3% of administered levodopa actually enters the brain unaltered”701_Katzun Pharm Split_….

 

✅ Correct answer: C. It is a precursor to dopamine.

424

Which is the correct property of the beta blocker?

A. Labetalol B1-B2-A1 antagonist

B. Atenolol B1-B2 antagonsit

C. Propanolol B1 selective antagonist

D. Pindolol B2 selective antagonist

Based on Katzung's Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024), here's the analysis of beta blocker properties:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. Labetalol B1-B2-A1 antagonist

✅ Correct

“Labetalol… β1 = β2 ≥ α1 > α2” — It is a mixed antagonist acting on β1, β2, and α1 receptors201_Katzun Pharm Split_….

B. Atenolol B1-B2 antagonist

❌ Wrong

Atenolol is β1-selective: “Atenolol… β1 >>> β2” — not a non-selective β-blocker201_Katzun Pharm Split_….

C. Propranolol B1 selective antagonist

❌ Wrong

Propranolol is non-selective: “Propranolol… β1 = β2”201_Katzun Pharm Split_….

D. Pindolol B2 selective antagonist

❌ Wrong

Pindolol is non-selective: “Pindolol… β1 = β2”201_Katzun Pharm Split_….

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. Labetalol B1-B2-A1 antagonist

Let me know if you'd like a visual beta-blocker classification table.

425

Which drug is not appropriately matched to its site of action?

A. Spironolactone and the collecting duct

B. Frusemide and the ascending loop of Henle

C. Triamterene and the descending loop of Henle

D. Thiazides and the proximal part of the distal tubule

Here is the evaluation of each diuretic–site of action match, based strictly on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, 2024 edition:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Quote

A. Spironolactone and the collecting duct

✅ Correct

“Spironolactone is an aldosterone antagonist that acts at the late distal tubule and collecting duct to block sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Frusemide and the ascending loop of Henle

✅ Correct

“Frusemide (furosemide) is a loop diuretic that acts at the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle by inhibiting the Na⁺/K⁺/2Cl⁻ cotransporter.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. Triamterene and the descending loop of Henle

❌ Incorrect

“Triamterene is a potassium-sparing diuretic that acts on the collecting duct, inhibiting epithelial sodium channels (ENaC). It does not act on the descending loop of Henle.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Thiazides and the proximal part of the distal tubule

✅ Correct

“Thiazide diuretics act on the early distal convoluted tubule, inhibiting the Na⁺/Cl⁻ cotransporter.” This matches “proximal part of the distal tubule.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

❌ Correct answer (not appropriately matched): C. Triamterene and the descending loop of Henle

Let me know if you'd like a nephron diagram with labeled drug targets.

426

Which anti-hypertensive medication activates the bradykinin system?

A. ACE-I

B. Thiazide

C. Angiotensin-receptor blocker

D. Beta-blocker
