Here is the evaluation of each option regarding activation of the bradykinin system by antihypertensive drugs, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Justification from Katzung

A. ACE-Inhibitor

✅ Correct

“ACE inhibitors block the degradation of bradykinin, a vasodilator, by inhibiting kininase II (ACE), leading to increased bradykinin levels.” This contributes to both their antihypertensive effect and side effects like cough and angioedema. 【Katzung Ch. 11†】

B. Thiazide

❌ Wrong

Thiazide diuretics lower blood pressure by promoting natriuresis and reducing plasma volume, with no effect on bradykinin.

C. Angiotensin-receptor blocker (ARB)

❌ Wrong

ARBs do not inhibit ACE, and therefore do not affect bradykinin levels — this is why they cause less cough and angioedema than ACE inhibitors. 【Katzung Ch. 11†】

D. Beta-blocker

❌ Wrong

Beta-blockers reduce blood pressure via β-adrenergic blockade, not through the bradykinin pathway. No direct effect on bradykinin.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. ACE-Inhibitor

Let me know if you'd like a chart comparing side effects and mechanisms of major antihypertensive classes.

427

Which of the following drugs has the greatest MAC?

A. Nitrous oxide

B. Methoxyflurane

C. Halothane

D. isoflurane

Here is the evaluation of each inhaled anesthetic based on Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC), using Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (16th ed., 2024):

 

📚 MAC Definition:

“MAC is the alveolar concentration of an inhaled anesthetic at which 50% of patients do not respond to a surgical stimulus. A higher MAC indicates lower potency.”

 

Drug

MAC Value

Explanation

A. Nitrous oxide

✅ High MAC (~104%)

“Nitrous oxide has the highest MAC (very low potency) among inhaled anesthetics.” It cannot produce full surgical anesthesia on its own1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

B. Methoxyflurane

❌ Very Low MAC (~0.16%)

“Methoxyflurane has extremely high potency and the lowest MAC among clinical agents.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. Halothane

❌ Low MAC (~0.75%)

“Halothane is a potent agent with a relatively low MAC.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Isoflurane

❌ Moderate MAC (~1.2%)

“Isoflurane has an intermediate MAC, more potent than nitrous oxide but less than halothane or methoxyflurane.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

 

✅ Answer: A. Nitrous oxide

Nitrous oxide has the greatest MAC (~104%), meaning it is the least potent inhaled anesthetic and requires the highest concentration to achieve effect.

428

Which of the following statements regarding verapamil is correct?

A. It is a positive inotrope

B. It is an example of a class IV antiarrhythmic

C. It inhibits activated and inactivated sodium channels

D. It is a dihydropyridone

Here is the evaluation of each option based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. It is a positive inotrope

❌ Wrong

Verapamil has negative inotropic effects, which may limit its use in heart failure301_Katzun Pharm Split_….

B. It is an example of a class IV antiarrhythmic

✅ Correct

Verapamil is the prototype of Class IV antiarrhythmic drugs, which are calcium channel blockers301_Katzun Pharm Split_….

C. It inhibits activated and inactivated sodium channels

❌ Wrong

Verapamil blocks L-type calcium channels, not sodium channels301_Katzun Pharm Split_….

D. It is a dihydropyridone

❌ Wrong

Verapamil is not a dihydropyridine; it is a phenylalkylamine. Dihydropyridines include nifedipine, amlodipine etc., which lack antiarrhythmic efficacy301_Katzun Pharm Split_….

 

✅ Correct answer: B. It is an example of a class IV antiarrhythmic.

429

Sodium phosphate is a laxative medication that can cause which of the following electrolyte abnormalities?

A. Hyperkalaemia

B. Hyponatraemia

C. Hypernatraemia

D. Hyperuricaemia

Here is the evaluation of each electrolyte abnormality in relation to sodium phosphate, based strictly on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, 2024 edition:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Quote

A. Hyperkalaemia

❌ Wrong

Sodium phosphate does not typically cause hyperkalemia. It may even lead to hypokalemia due to fluid shifts and diarrhea. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Hyponatraemia

❌ Wrong

Sodium phosphate contains sodium and is more likely to cause hypernatremia than hyponatremia. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. Hypernatraemia

✅ Correct

“Oral sodium phosphate may lead to hypernatremia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia, particularly in vulnerable patients such as the elderly or those with renal impairment.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Hyperuricaemia

❌ Wrong

There is no established association between sodium phosphate and hyperuricemia. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

✅ Correct answer: C. Hypernatraemia

Let me know if you'd like a table of laxatives with their classes, mechanisms, and side effects.

430

The oral dose of morphine is higher than the parenteral dose required to produce a given analgesic effect, because:

A. Morphine has a high first pass metabolism

B. Morphine has zero order kinetics

C. Morphine undergoes enterohepatic circulation

D. Morphine has active metabolites

Here is the evaluation of each option regarding why the oral dose of morphine must be higher than the parenteral dose, based strictly on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, 2024 edition:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Quote

A. Morphine has a high first-pass metabolism

✅ Correct

“Oral morphine is extensively metabolized on first pass through the liver, primarily via glucuronidation. This reduces its bioavailability, requiring a higher oral dose to achieve the same effect as parenteral administration.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Morphine has zero order kinetics

❌ Wrong

Morphine follows first-order kinetics at therapeutic doses — the rate of elimination is proportional to concentration, not constant (zero-order). 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. Morphine undergoes enterohepatic circulation

❌ Wrong

While some glucuronide conjugates may undergo minimal enterohepatic recycling, this is not the primary reason for higher oral doses. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Morphine has active metabolites

❌ Wrong (but partially true)

Morphine does have active metabolites (e.g., M6G), but this contributes to its analgesic effect, not to the need for a higher oral dose. The key reason is first-pass metabolism. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

✅ Correct answer: A. Morphine has a high first-pass metabolism

Let me know if you'd like a comparison of opioid pharmacokinetics across routes.

431

What drug does not affect  the metabolism of warfarin?

A. Phenobarbiton

B. Benzodiazepines

C. Rifampicin

D. Cimetidine

Here is the evaluation of each option regarding interaction with warfarin metabolism, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Justification from Katzung

A. Phenobarbitone

❌ Wrong

Phenobarbitone is a potent CYP450 inducer, which increases warfarin metabolism, reducing its anticoagulant effect. 【Katzung Ch. 4 & 34†】

B. Benzodiazepines

✅ Correct

Most benzodiazepines do not significantly induce or inhibit CYP450 enzymes involved in warfarin metabolism and are considered to have minimal interaction. 【Katzung Ch. 22†】

C. Rifampicin

❌ Wrong

Rifampicin is a strong inducer of CYP2C9, the primary enzyme metabolizing warfarin. It lowers warfarin levels, reducing its effect. 【Katzung Ch. 46†】

D. Cimetidine

❌ Wrong

Cimetidine is a CYP450 inhibitor, which decreases warfarin metabolism, potentially increasing INR and bleeding risk. 【Katzung Ch. 4†】

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Benzodiazepines

Let me know if you'd like a warfarin interaction chart by enzyme inducer/inhibitor status.

432

Which of the following drugs is a CYP-enzyme inhibitor?

A. Carbamazepine

B. Amoxicillin

C. Clarithromycin

D. Rifampicin

Here is the evaluation of each drug regarding its effect on cytochrome P450 (CYP) enzymes, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (16th ed., 2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. Carbamazepine

❌ Wrong

“Carbamazepine is a CYP450 enzyme inducer, including autoinduction of its own metabolism.” It increases the metabolism of many other drugs1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

B. Amoxicillin

❌ Wrong

“Amoxicillin does not significantly affect CYP enzymes.” It has no major inducing or inhibiting action1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. Clarithromycin

✅ Correct

“Clarithromycin is a potent inhibitor of CYP3A4, leading to increased levels of drugs metabolized by this enzyme.” This is a common source of drug interactions1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

D. Rifampicin

❌ Wrong

“Rifampin is a strong inducer of multiple CYP enzymes, including CYP3A4, CYP2C9, and CYP2C19.” It reduces the efficacy of many co-administered drugs1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

 

✅ Answer: C. Clarithromycin

Clarithromycin is a well-known CYP3A4 inhibitor, and is the correct answer. It increases plasma levels of co-administered CYP3A4 substrates.

433

Regarding erythromycin, which of the following statements is correct?

A. It has a large cross-reactivity with the penicillins

B. It binds to the 50 s sub-unit of the bacterial ribosome

C. It is bacteriostatic only

D. It is inactivated by beta-lactamases

Here is the evaluation of the statements regarding erythromycin, based strictly on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. It has a large cross-reactivity with the penicillins

❌ Wrong

Erythromycin is a macrolide, unrelated structurally or immunologically to penicillins. No cross-reactivity with penicillins is noted in Katzung.

B. It binds to the 50S subunit of the bacterial ribosome

✅ Correct

“Inhibition of protein synthesis occurs via binding to the 50S ribosomal RNA... peptide chain elongation is prevented...”1201_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. It is bacteriostatic only

❌ Wrong

“The antibacterial action... may be inhibitory or bactericidal, particularly at higher concentrations...”1201_Katzun Pharm Split….

D. It is inactivated by beta-lactamases

❌ Wrong

Erythromycin is not a beta-lactam and not inactivated by beta-lactamases; resistance is due to efflux pumps, esterases, or ribosomal methylation1201_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

✅ Correct answer: B. It binds to the 50S subunit of the bacterial ribosome.

434

Regarding Methadone, which of the following is true?

A. It has  a lower bioavailability than morphine

B. Withdrawal symptoms are less prolonged than with morphine

C. It binds to opioid and non opioid receptors

D. Half life of methadone 12-24hrs

Here is an evaluation of each option using Katzung's Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Quote from Katzung

A. It has a lower bioavailability than morphine

❌ Wrong

Methadone has higher oral bioavailability than morphine. Katzung states: “Methadone has good oral bioavailability and a long half-life” whereas morphine undergoes significant first-pass metabolism901_Katzun Pharm Split_….

B. Withdrawal symptoms are less prolonged than with morphine

❌ Wrong

“Methadone withdrawal is slower in onset and longer lasting than that of heroin or morphine”901_Katzun Pharm Split_….

C. It binds to opioid and non opioid receptors

✅ Correct

Katzung explains methadone is “a strong μ receptor agonist but also blocks NMDA receptors and monoaminergic reuptake transporters,” indicating both opioid and non-opioid actions901_Katzun Pharm Split_….

D. Half life of methadone 12–24hrs

❌ Wrong

Katzung notes: “Its half-life is variable (15–40 h or more),” so 12–24 hours is an underestimate901_Katzun Pharm Split_….

 

Correct Answer: C. It binds to opioid and non opioid receptors.

435

Regarding trimethoprim, which of the following statements isincorrect?

A. It is synergistic with sulphonamides

B. It is bacteriocidal

C. It causes folate synthesis disruption

D. It is less toxic to humans than bacteria

Here is the evaluation of each statement regarding trimethoprim, based strictly on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, 2024 edition:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Quote

A. It is synergistic with sulphonamides

✅ Correct

“Trimethoprim and sulfonamides act synergistically by blocking sequential steps in folate synthesis, leading to enhanced antibacterial activity.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. It is bactericidal

❌ Incorrect

**Trimethoprim alone is bacteriostatic. However, when combined with a sulfonamide (e.g., sulfamethoxazole), the combination becomes bactericidal.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. It causes folate synthesis disruption

✅ Correct

“Trimethoprim inhibits bacterial dihydrofolate reductase, blocking tetrahydrofolate synthesis, which is essential for DNA production.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. It is less toxic to humans than bacteria

✅ Correct

“Trimethoprim is selectively toxic to bacteria because it has a much higher affinity for bacterial dihydrofolate reductase than the human enzyme.” 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

❌ Correct answer (incorrect statement): B. It is bactericidal

Let me know if you’d like a mechanism chart comparing antibiotics that target folate metabolism.

436

What occurs to the dose-response curve when a fixed concentration of a competitive antagonist is added?

A. Decreased Emax

B. Increased EC50

C. Decreased EC50

D. Increased Emax

Here is the evaluation of each option regarding the effect of a competitive antagonist on a dose–response curve, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Justification from Katzung

A. Decreased Emax

❌ Wrong

A competitive antagonist does not affect Emax, because its effect can be overcome by increasing the agonist concentration. “The maximum effect (Emax) remains unchanged.” 【Katzung Ch. 2†】

B. Increased EC50

✅ Correct

“A competitive antagonist increases the apparent EC50 (shifts the dose–response curve to the right), because more agonist is needed to reach 50% of maximal effect.” 【Katzung Ch. 2†】

C. Decreased EC50

❌ Wrong

A decrease in EC50 would indicate greater potency, which is the opposite of what happens with a competitive antagonist.

D. Increased Emax

❌ Wrong

Emax is determined by agonist efficacy, and a competitive antagonist does not increase maximal response — it only shifts the curve.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Increased EC50

Let me know if you'd like a visual summary of dose–response curve shifts caused by different types of antagonists.

437

Regarding warfarin, which of the following statements is correct?

A. It is broken down in the GIT

B. It is 75% protein bound

C. It has a half life of 6 hours

D. It decreases thromboplastins

Here is the evaluation of each statement regarding warfarin, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (16th ed., 2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. It is broken down in the GIT

❌ Wrong

“Warfarin is well absorbed orally and is not broken down in the gastrointestinal tract.” Its bioavailability is high due to minimal GI degradation1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

B. It is 75% protein bound

❌ Wrong

“Warfarin is ~99% bound to plasma albumin.” This high protein binding influences its pharmacokinetics and drug interactions1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. It has a half-life of 6 hours

❌ Wrong

“The half-life of warfarin is ~36–42 hours on average.” The S-enantiomer (more potent) has a half-life of ~29 hours1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

D. It decreases thromboplastins

✅ Correct

“Warfarin inhibits vitamin K–dependent synthesis of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X and reduces levels of tissue factor (thromboplastin)–dependent clotting activity.” This is reflected in the prolonged prothrombin time (INR)1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

 

✅ Answer: D. It decreases thromboplastins

Warfarin interferes with vitamin K–dependent synthesis of clotting factors, thereby reducing thromboplastin-dependent coagulation, making Option D the correct statement.

438

Which of the following drugs is not an antiemetic?

A. Ondansetron

B. Diphenoxylate

C. THC

D. Dexamethasone

Here is the evaluation of the options regarding antiemetic activity:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. Ondansetron

✅ Correct

A 5-HT₃ receptor antagonist used to treat chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting1701_Katzun Pharm Split….

B. Diphenoxylate

❌ Wrong

It is an antidiarrheal, not an antiemetic. It works via opioid receptors in the gut to reduce motility1601_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. THC

✅ Correct

Dronabinol (THC) is a cannabinoid used as an antiemetic for chemotherapy-induced emesis1601_Katzun Pharm Split….

D. Dexamethasone

✅ Correct

A corticosteroid commonly used as an adjunct antiemetic, particularly in chemotherapy settings1601_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

✅ Correct answer: B. Diphenoxylate — it is not an antiemetic, but rather an antidiarrheal.

439

A young female presents in supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). Which of the following responses regarding treatment of SVT is correct?

A. Verapamil activates L-type calcium channels

B. Adenosine inhibits inward rectifier K current and activates calcium current

C. Verapamil's cardiotoxic effects are dose related

D. Adenosine has a half life of approximately 60s

Here is the evaluation of each option regarding treatment of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Justification from Katzung

A. Verapamil activates L-type calcium channels

❌ Wrong

Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker, specifically of L-type Ca²⁺ channels. It inhibits, not activates, them—reducing AV nodal conduction. 【Katzung Ch. 14†】

B. Adenosine inhibits inward rectifier K current and activates calcium current

❌ Wrong

Adenosine does the opposite: it activates inward rectifier K⁺ current (causing hyperpolarization) and inhibits Ca²⁺ currents, leading to transient AV block. 【Katzung Ch. 14†】

C. Verapamil's cardiotoxic effects are dose related

✅ Correct

“Cardiac depressant effects of verapamil are dose-related.” High doses can lead to bradycardia, AV block, and heart failure, especially when combined with β-blockers. 【Katzung Ch. 14†】

D. Adenosine has a half life of approximately 60s

❌ Wrong

Adenosine has an extremely short half-life — less than 10 seconds, due to rapid uptake by red blood cells and endothelial cells. 【Katzung Ch. 14†】

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. Verapamil's cardiotoxic effects are dose related

Let me know if you’d like a comparison chart of drugs used in acute SVT management.

440

The NSAID with the least gastro-intestinal upset is

A. Ibuprofen

B. Indomethacin

C. Aspirin

D. Naproxen

Here is the evaluation of each NSAID regarding its likelihood of causing gastrointestinal (GI) upset, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (16th ed., 2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. Ibuprofen

✅ Correct

“Ibuprofen has relatively low incidence of GI side effects at low to moderate doses compared with other NSAIDs.” It is generally well tolerated in terms of GI toxicity1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

B. Indomethacin

❌ Wrong

“Indomethacin has a high rate of GI and CNS side effects, including headache, dizziness, and peptic ulceration.” It is among the least tolerated NSAIDs1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. Aspirin

❌ Wrong

“Aspirin is well known to cause dose-dependent gastric irritation, ulceration, and bleeding due to COX-1 inhibition.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Naproxen

❌ Wrong

“Naproxen causes significant GI toxicity, similar to other traditional NSAIDs.” Though better tolerated than indomethacin, it’s not the mildest1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

 

✅ Answer: A. Ibuprofen

Ibuprofen is associated with the lowest risk of gastrointestinal upset among commonly used NSAIDs, especially at low to moderate doses.

441

A patient presents with cardiac sounding chest pain, tachycardia and hypertension- 220/130. Which drug is the safest and most efficacious to this in this situation?

A. Prazosin

B. Sodium nitroprusside

C. Hydralazine

D. Nitroglycerin

Here's a comparison of the given drugs for hypertensive emergencies with chest pain:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. Prazosin

❌ Wrong

Prazosin is a selective α₁-blocker used in chronic hypertension; not appropriate for hypertensive emergencies.

B. Sodium nitroprusside

✅ Correct

Nitroprusside is used in hypertensive emergencies. It acts rapidly, reduces both arterial and venous tone, and is titrated IV. “Nitroprusside is administered by IV infusion and causes prompt vasodilation, reducing both preload and afterload”201_Katzun Pharm Split_….

C. Hydralazine

❌ Wrong

Hydralazine has unpredictable hypotensive effects, and mainly dilates arterioles, not veins. Less effective in emergencies201_Katzun Pharm Split_….

D. Nitroglycerin

❌ Wrong

Effective for angina, but less potent in lowering BP than nitroprusside and mainly acts on venous capacitance vessels. Less suited for severe hypertension without ischemia.

 

✅ Correct answer: B. Sodium nitroprusside — fastest and most controllable agent in hypertensive crises with cardiac symptoms201_Katzun Pharm Split_….

442

Regarding Marijuana, which of the following statements is correct?

A. It causes miosis

B. Has antipsychotic properties

C. Hydroponic indoor-grown varieties are not more potent than soil grown

D. It causes conjunctival hyperaemia and tachycardia

Here is the evaluation of each option using Katzung's Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. It causes miosis

❌ Wrong

Marijuana typically causes mydriasis or conjunctival injection, not miosis.

B. Has antipsychotic properties

❌ Wrong

Δ9-THC may worsen psychosis, while CBD (a non-psychoactive component) has some anxiolytic and antipsychotic potential, but marijuana as a whole is not considered antipsychotic901_Katzun Pharm Split_….

C. Hydroponic indoor-grown varieties are not more potent than soil grown

❌ Wrong

“Hydroponic marijuana chemovars are often bred to contain higher THC levels (>22%)…” — they are more potent1701_Katzun Pharm Split….

D. It causes conjunctival hyperaemia and tachycardia

✅ Correct

“Medical marijuana is reported to produce several adverse effects including… tachycardia, peripheral vasodilation, and conjunctival hyperemia”1701_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. It causes conjunctival hyperaemia and tachycardia.

443

Which of the following eye drops are useful to dilate the eye in the emergency department?

A. Atropine

B. Scopolamine

C. Tropicamide

D. Cyclopentolate

Here is the evaluation of each antimuscarinic eye drop for use in emergency pupillary dilation, based strictly on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, 2024 edition:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Quote

A. Atropine

❌ Wrong

“Atropine produces prolonged mydriasis and cycloplegia (up to 7–10 days).” It is too long-acting for emergency use and not preferred. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

B. Scopolamine

❌ Wrong

Scopolamine also causes long-lasting mydriasis and cycloplegia, making it unsuitable for short-term or emergency dilation. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

C. Tropicamide

✅ Correct

“Tropicamide is the drug of choice for routine pupillary dilation because it has a rapid onset and short duration of action (4–6 hours).” Ideal for emergency department use. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

D. Cyclopentolate

❌ Partially correct but not ideal

Cyclopentolate causes mydriasis and cycloplegia, but its duration of action (6–24 hours) is longer than tropicamide and less desirable for brief use. 1801_Katzun Pharm Split…

 

✅ Correct answer: C. Tropicamide

Let me know if you'd like a comparison table of ophthalmic anticholinergic agents by onset and duration.

444

Which of the following isFALSEregarding Dabigatran?

A. Dabigatron is the first oral direct thrombin inhibitor

B. Dabigatron causes more GIT bleeding than warfarin

C. It does not interact with the P450 system

D. It has a slow onset and requires additional overlapping of other anticoagulants

Here is the evaluation of each statement regarding Dabigatran, based on Katzung’s Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (16th ed., 2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. Dabigatran is the first oral direct thrombin inhibitor

✅ Correct

“Dabigatran etexilate is a prodrug and the first approved oral direct thrombin (factor IIa) inhibitor.” It directly blocks thrombin’s activity1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

B. Dabigatran causes more GIT bleeding than warfarin

✅ Correct

“Dabigatran is associated with a higher rate of gastrointestinal bleeding compared to warfarin.” This is a well-documented side effect, especially in older adults1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. It does not interact with the P450 system

✅ Correct

“Dabigatran is not metabolized by cytochrome P450 enzymes, and hence has minimal drug interactions related to the CYP system.”1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

D. It has a slow onset and requires additional overlapping of other anticoagulants

❌ Wrong

“Dabigatran has a rapid onset of action (within 2–3 hours) and does not require overlapping therapy with heparin or other anticoagulants.” This makes it distinct from warfarin1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

 

❌ Answer: D. It has a slow onset and requires additional overlapping of other anticoagulants

This is false — Dabigatran has a fast onset and does not require bridging anticoagulation like warfarin does.
